chapters.text: and what support can be provided to meet regulatory requirements um for example fca and the united kingdom yeah well when it comes to regulatory requirements of course the adapts or the companies that are building their product on top of us have to have to consider their own regulatory environment and the requirements that they have to operate in but what we do try to do in as part of the platform is provide tools that make it easier to meet those requirements so for example if you're issuing a token there is uh there there is a check box there for koic controls to be used in in the token issuance um our file system our distributed file system it's possible to have what we call controlled mutability if you need to delete something from the file system you can get a proof from us from the network that the item has actually been deleted and it's proof in the sense that there's a consensus in the nodes that vote on whether that file has actually been removed from the file system you know that's useful for things like gdpr and maybe other things as well so we build features that are meant to support the regulatory requirements of the different use cases and industries but in terms of uh actually providing that you know they're building the product in such a way that it's compliant of course that's up to the dapps themselves all right thanks mance and okay i know uh you know we're gonna jump into a few more questions just a note for the folks who might have joined a little bit late uh we do take the questions beforehand so we're not able to answer any that come through the chat but please save those and make sure that you submit them for um for next month's town hall leemon is anyone working on an erc20

chapters.text: you mentioned previously that council members do not own the coin stake to their nodes from treasury and if they did that would you wouldn't be a fan of that but don't the council coins oh no this is what's cool yes it is the council that makes all these decisions so the council stakes the coins to the council members when we have community nodes they may stake some of the coins to community nodes but the council as a whole makes that decision so the whole council has to vote and have a majority voting to make a decision like that once 139th of the nodes is given to one of the 39 council members you know that's how it will end up before we have community members then that council member gets the benefit from it but they can't unilaterally by themselves take their share of the coins and sell them and go off and have a vacation in the bahamas they can't do that they don't have control of it by themselves they just are one vote on the whole council while the whole council is deciding what to do with all of the coins so it's uh it's it's like congress voting on what to do with money no single congress person can go take their share of of all the money in the world and go off and do something with it they just have their piece of the vote and then it's the vote as a whole that decides what happens with the money same thing with the council so councilman a single council member does not get control of a single share of those coins but the council as a whole controls all the coins so that's very important for governance for good governance and for preventing uh one rogue actor from doing something bad which is what we're always and that's what ledgers are all about you don't never want one rogue actor to be able to do something bad you want to be decentralized or everyone has to agree or at least you know a fraction of them all right thank you for clarifying leemon mance will there ever be a token burn

entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our monthly Town Hall.

Timestamps for this video:
0:00 Intro
1:38 When Council members vote on major decisions, who makes the decision on behalf of each member?
3:00 When a Council members complete their term, what will be the relationship between ex-members and Hedera?
4:48 Does Hedera Token Service (HTS) have a mechanism that allows for royalties?
6:37 Does the entire Governing Council know about all upcoming announcements, prospective Council members, and projects that are being developed?
8:24 Comparing DLT adoption with the history of the internet, what year are we in now?
9:31 Will The Coupon Bureau also use the Hedera Token Service (HTS) to issue coupons?
10:37 Ethereum has hit technical limitations regarding scalability. Can Hedera use appnets or Hedera Consensus Service (HCS) to achieve layer two solutions?
12:42 What is Mance's favorite use case?
14:46 What is the Council's role in the Hedera Improvement Proposal (HIP) program?
16:28 When can the general public run mirror nodes?
17:38  What is the difference between digital payments and digital currencies?
18:58 Is it possible for Council members or governments to prevent users or companies from accessing Hedera?
20:17 When will we see wide-scale adoption of Hedera?
23:18 Why is there a maximum supply of HBAR?
23:39 Will blockchain technology become affordable for people in daily life?
24:27 Could a node be positioned in a satellite (For example Starlink)? [Note: There are currently running mainnet nodes on every continent except Antarctica!]
25:25 How can Hedera (and HTS) be useful to the hospitality industry? 
26:14 Why is the Hedera wallet not recommended?
28:08 How can a FinTech startup leverage Hedera and what support can be provided to meet regulatory requirements?
30:13 Is anyone working on an ERC-20 converter?
31:37 Elaboration on 2021 being the year of "scale."
35:03 Don't the Council members decide how the Treasury coins are staked to their nodes?
37:09 Will there ever be a token burn?
37:58 Would trusted community members be able to run a node?
39:28 What would happen to the Hedera network if a CME (coronal mass ejection) wiped out the world's power supply?
41:58 Why will industries choose to build on Hedera over other competing DLTs?
43:32 What is the minimum estimated required transactions per second in order to support a fully tokenized world?
44:47 How to apply for a position with Hedera if there are no current positions available that are a good fit?
46:19 What mathematical unsolved problems is Leemon still working on?
51:52 Further elaboration on Council members that are owned by governments. 
53:19 Leemon shares more details about the charity auction for his HBAR coins.
55:39 What Hollywood stars should play Mance and Leemon in the Hedera origin story on the big screen!?

Developer resources:
Chat: https://hedera.com/discord
Docs: https://docs.hedera.com/guides
GitHub: https://github.com/hashgraph
Testnet Access: https://portal.hedera.com

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hedera
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://hedera.com/discord
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Whitepapers: https://hedera.com/papers

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | March 2021

chapters.text: welcome to everyone thank you for your flexibility with us um last week was a bit of a challenge in dallas so we rescheduled and we are so glad that you have chosen to spend your friday morning or afternoon or maybe friday evening with us and so for those of you who are kick-starting the weekend we hope this is an enjoyable way to do so and just for those we we may have some new folks on what we try to do here is go through questions that were were provided beforehand and through the form that sent out to the community uh we are not able to answer anything that's in the any questions in the chat but please you know do send those in for the next session we try to get through as many as we possibly can and we typically have more questions and we can answer in an hour and so anything that you can find on the website or that we have uh you know in other places or that has previously been addressed on a town hall those are things that we we tend to um to skip over or potentially do at the end because we know we have a number of folks on this call and in the community who have been with us a long time and uh you know don't want to hear us just repeating ourselves so we always try to bring you something new and different and the questions that are most timely and relevant and with that i will kick off and start to ask some questions of the folks that you want to hear from so um leemon to start us off is there a way for the communities
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: to suggest features and standards for hedera oh great question i am hip to that so we now have the hip the hedera improvement process hip and there are uh several hips out i think hip one i think was the one that i wrote on um checksums and then lots of people gave feedback we have another hip that explains the hip process and defines it and there's other hips i think in the process we're just getting started with this the idea is that the community as a whole proposes things gives their feedback on things tells how it should be tweaked and so on and so they just like an rfc for the internet and um you know all those other things erc and there's other other types of um processes for giving suggestions and then creating standards and so the community itself will be creating these standards i love this and and we expect to do more and more of that as time goes on but yeah i'm very very excited about our new hip process all right thanks leemon um you know uh we are getting some questions i think we've addressed this a little bit but we wanted to um to address it today what is the expected worldwide performance of smart
chapters.title: Can the community suggest features and standards for Hedera Hashgraph?

chapters.text: contracts on the hedera network compared to the ethereum network especially once the hedera network is deployed and tuned to full scale sure so we have smart contracts and smart contracts can do anything they're turing complete but they have limitations in speed and other things and so what you want to do is find ways of doing your business logic in a way that is fast compared to a smart contract so we have hcs and hts so if you recall hcs is our consensus service it allows you to build an app.net and you can run you can write your program in any language you want and it runs at native speed which is you know as fast as you could possibly get furthermore since it's running on one app net of many it has that whole app net to itself and maybe doesn't have a whole lot of other traffic and so it has the whole computer to itself and can run much faster so if you really want speed you want to be able to run in any language have it compiled run on its own little network and and then divide up the the work between different little networks that's what the consensus service is for and then sometimes you want even lower latency than that and you want it even more convenience than that and so then what you do is you take specific items and instead of having them as smart contracts you build it into the bottom layer itself you make them native to the ledger and that's the name the hedera token service is making tokens native to the ledger itself and so you can do many thousands of token transfers per second and uh and you have all the security of hedera you don't have to look at a smart contract and wonder if there's any bugs in it it's just hedera itself is doing the token so lots of nice advantages to having tokens on hedera itself oh plus you have this great interoperability is that you can transfer tokens from one person to another even if they're different types of tokens and you can do it atomically and do it multi-way so i give alice a token she gives bob a token bob gives me a token and there are three different kinds of tokens created by different people but we have a single transaction that does it all maybe it moves some h bars too maybe um i'm giving alice several different kinds of tokens at the same time all of that uh and then it's just it's atomic either the whole transaction happens or none of it happens so lots of nice advantages to that so the answer is yeah you can always do smart contracts but if you want real speed you want to use any language you want and you even want to have parallelization then you can use the cert consensus service and if it's tokens you can use the token service for extra speed all right thanks leemon mance this next one is for you
chapters.title: What is the expected worldwide performance of smart contracts on Hedera Hashgraph?

chapters.text: um there has been a lot of discussion especially as the price of transactions on various platforms has um you know has fluctuated and gone up um can you share your feedback and insights on how the price of hbar as it rises will impact transaction fees and the cost of using the network or platform yeah well so let me just start by saying that in the past what is this this is the end of february so in the past six weeks the price of the token has gone from approximately 3 cents to i don't know 12 to 15 cents the price per transaction hasn't budged it's been fixed and that's by design the costs of transactions are denominated in dollars and it doesn't matter what the price of the token is it's you know it's going to fluctuate it's going to go up and down but anybody building on the platform that needs to plan for the future what they're you know understand what their future costs are going to be when they make api calls they don't have to worry about that and what actually happens behind the scenes is that there is an sdk that developers can use as part of building their applications and when they want to make api calls it will tell them how many hbar is required for a given api call and i think it's about an once every hour leemon you can correct me but i think it's about once every hour the number of hbars required for a given api call is adjusted based on the the current average price of h bars in the market so uh you know we we understood from the very beginning that that was a problem that had to be resolved and so it was built in you know the solution i described as built in from day one all right thanks mance um leemonn uh can hedera be

thinking about a worldwide adoption of a cryptocurrency or competing distributed app given the current economic and big tech climate why shouldn't folks be worried about this and what measures or mechanisms are in place to protect the integrity yeah well first off you know it's interesting because when people think of the council there's just sort of this knee-jerk reaction to think of it as this single monolithic entity right which is as far from the truth as it can be the council if you know words matter right the use that which where which words you use to describe something matter we should probably call the council a distributed community of organizations that are working together to prioritize features and provide governance of the network and the real the heart of the question goes to what's the right governance model to prevent this sort of collusion or you know attack if you will on the integrity of the system and if you think about governance models you can have a dictator a dictator has total control uh and it's really easy to corrupt by by comparison you know if you if you can persuade a single party to to do something whether that's through bribery or you know extortion or whatever or maybe they just have poor judgment you do have to worry about a dictator being whimsical perhaps in their decision-making process that's what the whole industry is trying that held a dollar would have a say in the management of the policies associated with with that currency that doesn't work either if the decisions are complex so if you have really simple decisions any given other platform well ask yourself that question right if what you're trying to prevent is this community to become bad actors in some way then what forces or roadblocks can you put in place to prevent that sort of thing what we've done is chosen this community of governors if you want to think maybe use that word uh to be distributed across industries pd to be geo-distributed and ultimately distributed through time we believe that that is more decentralized than many of the other platforms today that uh you know people would just immediately say oh no they're decentralized sending transactions through the nodes how is dropping every 15th transaction prevented when the transaction is sent to a down node oh yeah no transactions are dropped so that doesn't happen so the way it works is that like what the sdk does is it'll pick a node at random and if that node you can't connect to it it just goes to a different node it doesn't drop the transaction you don't lose a transaction at worst you would lose the one or two seconds or whatever it takes you to realize that that node is not responding you could even make that shorter if you wanted to so so nothing is lost furthermore if you wanted to be smart what you could do is program it to say um don't even just choose them at random choose at random those that i have not had any problems with recently and then you even saved the second or two of time that it would have taken you to wait to know that it's not good so if a node's not good you talk to it less often so we absolutely recommend that you pick nodes at random maybe even pick at random where your distribution is you don't pick it so often if it has been down recently but we definitely do not lose any transactions that way the only way you could lose a transaction is if you handed the transaction to the node and then the node crashed which is you know extremely low probability if that happened yeah then you lose your transaction you have to try again you just try again so you know you wait it waited three or four seconds you say oh it never reached consensus and then you try again so or wait two minutes and you know it's out actually has gossip to all the nodes and so at that point not only can you not undo your transaction but it's you have now received credit for having submitted it and whoever submitted first will win so the contest to be the first one to get it in is going to be a fraction of a second now it's going to be a larger fraction of a second when we're talking about multiple computers than if we're talking about a single computer so that fraction of a second is going to be bigger for a network than it is for a single computer the new york stock exchange but your bid becomes irrevocable you can't undo it within a small number of milliseconds and um and reach has reached all the nodes and has its point in history essentially set within a fraction of a second and then within a few seconds you get consensus and you could say oh that's terrible a few seconds to get consensus well sure but the consensus is just putting the stamp of approval on something that happened during that first fraction of a second and furthermore because it's a ledger you can talk about well it's the bid and the ask being matched i mean we know who's gonna who's going to have it be sold to them but we can also do clearing and settling all at once you give me the stock and i give you the money at the same time and all that could happen within three seconds so this is the nice thing is that with ledgers it doesn't take days to to do clearing and settling and you know if you send someone a wire it can take days everything can happen within those three seconds and so you've locked yourself in in a matter of milliseconds and then you find out the result of everything including clear and settling and all the other stuff within a few seconds so ledgers can be very good for markets i think and if you want to stop front running already being fast makes it harder but there's ways of you commit to a hash and you open the hash and you have punishment if you don't open the hash there's various ways you can entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our ninth Town Hall.

Timestamps for this video:
0:00 Intro
1:30 Can the community suggest features and standards for Hedera Hashgraph?
2:44 What is the expected worldwide performance of smart contracts on Hedera Hashgraph?
5:12 Feedback and insights on how the price of HBAR will impact transaction fees and the cost of using Hedera Hashgraph.
7:16 Can Hedera be used as a Lightning Network for Bitcoin to increase the speed of transactions on the Bitcoin network?
10:00 Is there a plan to prevent lost private keys on Hedera Hashgraph?
11:15 Where to find information about new tokens being minted using the Hedera Token Service (HTS)?
12:19 Does Leemon still feel that quantum computing isn't a threat to cryptocurrency? Could quantum computing benefit or enhance Hedera? 
17:50 Can the Hedera Governing Council change the rules around an app or cryptocurrency? Why shouldn't people be worried about this and what measures or mechanisms are in place to protect the integrity?
22:26 Is Hedera Hashgraph CO2 (carbon dioxide) neutral, positive or negative?
24:25 How many employees will Hedera Hashgraph have in the near and long term? 
27:03 Will Hedera Hashgraph provide an alternative to Facebook?
28:59 Are there still undiscovered use cases for Hedera Hashgraph?
31:42 What will stop people from turning Hedera tokenized assets into a Ponzi scheme? What is Hedera's ERC-20 equivalent called? 
34:59 How to contribute to the community if you are not a developer?
36:34 How is a dropped transaction prevented when the transaction is sent to a down node?
38:56 How will mission critical use cases and enterprises obtain HBAR?
41:32 Why is HBAR important?
42:56 Is there a plan to get more adoption from enterprise developers, in particular, DeFi? 
46:09 How could Hedera Hashgraph enable a stock market?
48:54 What is Hedera's approach to adoption in authoritarian countries who might see the decentralization of information as a threat to their regimes?
50:30 Does Mance and Leemon workout?
51:27 Can Leemon share more details around his metal HBAR coin?

Developer resources:
Chat: https://hedera.com/discord
Docs: https://docs.hedera.com/guides
GitHub: https://github.com/hashgraph
Testnet Access: https://portal.hedera.com

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hedera
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://hedera.com/discord
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Whitepapers: https://hedera.com/papers

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | February 2021

chapters.text: so um i think we probably have a number of new folks on the webinar today so i wanted to say hello to all of them and welcome to the community we are excited to have you here and then and as the girl scout saying goes also welcome to our longtime followers make new friends but keep the old you know one is silver and the other's gold so thank you all for being here uh just to share with the new folks who haven't uh seen this before and this is you know we do solicit questions beforehand and so the questions that we'll be answering today are ones that have come from the community over the last few weeks we do this every month we took a little bit of a break in december and we learned our lesson that we probably shouldn't take a break because we had so many questions come in in january so we will definitely not be able to get to all of them today we will try to get to as many as we possibly can but rest assured that we have um you know we know they are in there they are in the queue and we will try to make sure that we answer them um either in you know in faqs or somewhere else or next month if we run out of time we try to focus on content that is new and educational for the community so anything that is in an faq somewhere else or is already on our blog or our website we will you know we will try to avoid those because we want to spare people who have heard that probably more times than they can imagine and then the other thing that we do not do here is uh you know is to speculate on hbar we will let you guys have fun doing that and but to start off with i did want to have leemon just address you know
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: transaction prices because as we see some you know some changes in the price of hbar we have had some questions around um transaction pricing for transactions that happen on the network yeah this is great so we we have always said that there's volatility in the crypto market and certainly we're seeing a lot of volatility recently which is why we set the prices for the transactions in dollars and convert that to h bars and the conversion ratio automatically updates itself as the market fluctuates and so what it means is that if it goes up a million fold or goes down a millionth it doesn't matter the dollar price of the transaction stays the same and we smooth out the market a little bit so the market might get a little bit ahead of us or a little bit behind us but are a little bit ahead of us i guess either way uh but uh but that's what we do and so our prices are the same and so if the coin price triples the price of a transaction is still the same in fiat it's just um one-third in h bars but we we smooth out the volatility and so that was something we planned from the very beginning and i think that recent events are showing that hey that's a pretty good idea so that's what we have all right thank you leemon so we've got a lot to tackle today mance i'm going to jump right in the first question is for you is hedera a good fit for cbdc
chapters.title: Leemon Baird addresses transaction prices on the Hedera Hashgraph mainnet.

chapters.text: creation right so many of you may already be familiar with hcs and hedera consensus service in that architecture but as novia said we have a bunch of new people joining the community so i'm going to take just a moment to describe that with normal layer one networks they perform two functions transactions flow into the network and they get put into a consensus order a stream of order transactions is created and then those transactions flow into sort of the business logic layer which is normally referred to as smart contract layer and they get operated on in those smart contracts the the smart contracts operate on the transactions that have been ordered that has problems in that it can be slow you have all the smart contracts in the world created by all the developers using that platform competing for the same cpu cycles on that platform those the information flowing through the smart contracts has to be decrypted it can't be encrypted uh that's a big problem the industry is trying to resolve so it's you've got privacy or security uh pii concerns or you know just information generally you may not want to be public it's gonna be public if it's being operated on those smart contracts and and because of the the the congestion of the networks the cost to operate these smart contracts is really high what we did was we split the smart contracts layer off you can think of it conceptually like exposing just the consensus layer and moving the business logic into another network it could be a private network it could be a public network it's just not running on our main net nodes this architecture makes it possible to create a ledger for cbdc uh in it with the degree of flexibility and security and privacy and cost structure that you simply can't do on a public ledger using smart contracts for cbdc so the the simple answer to the question is yes the way in which it would be done presumably is that any government that wanted to create a cbdc would create a separate network that manages the ledger for their cbdc the hedera consensus service could play a role in putting transactions in order and the you know taking advantage of that public ledger trust model but the scalability the security the flexibility in being able to do anything you can imagine in a network for the management of this of this currency including kyc aml controls you can layer identity on top of it all of that could be done in the private network then of course markets that use the token the the coin could run directly on top of hedera you know there there are a lot of sort of secondary or tertiary uh uses of of the coin that could run on top of adera directly but the the actual ledger for the coin and the management of that would not be done directly on hedera so that's a little bit long-winded but um but hopefully that that makes sense and gives you a sense of how cbdc would work with with adera thanks man leemon do mirror nodes need constant human intervention and will
chapters.title: Is Hedera Hashgraph a good fit for CBDC creation?

chapters.text: the consensus layer eventually become autonomous like bitcoin okay so amir knows don't need constant human intervention all the mirror node is is a computer that is automatically downloading files continuously it checks the signatures on those files to make sure they really do represent what the by what the network as a whole has had as its consensus and then they parse it out and put it in a database and answer queries from users so that's what a mirror node is doing and we've written mirror node software and some people are running our software and then some people just written their own from scratch to read those files and download them and check their signatures and answer questions from them so that just happens autonomously if your computer goes offline for a while when it comes back online it should just be able to download you know keep downloading files and download the ones that it missed and and catch up shouldn't be a problem if if we change the format of the files themselves that of course if something happens very rarely but if we do that then if you've written your own software to parse those files you need to update your software i mean so i guess that's manual but if you're using our software you don't have to do that you just download our new software so it's pretty straightforward now that's for our current mirror nodes we do have um a different kind of mirror node that we may have in the future where your mirror node is just like a node on the network and in that case it's um i won't go into all the details but it should be able to do the things that the network does where it could automatically reconnect when it drops off and it'll be more interesting um just gives you lower um lower latency and gives you state proofs and things but we don't have state proofs yet but when we have state proofs we'll be improving the mirror nodes to allow you to have state proofs from the mirror node itself but right now what you can have is sort of like a state proof you can get from the mirror node the signatures on one of these files and then you can look in the file to see the information you're interested in so what we'll be changing the future is a more fine-grained one but but that will also be pretty autonomous and then even the software updates will be autonomous as for the main nets themselves the nodes are autonomous to upgrade the software right now what we do is have a human load the new software in and so um you know a lot of ledgers work that way if you want if there's going to be a new software version you have to download and decide whether to load it or not you do that manually we are actually we have code on the network that we haven't used yet but we're debugging and working with it that'll let even that happen automatically and so even the software upgrades will happen with no human involved at the at the node it'll just happen automatically if the if it is triggered by a transaction that was signed by more than two-thirds of the nodes so the consensus will do it and so that'll be coming um but right now the way it works is that a human updates the software but in the future even that will be automated so that's where we're headed thanks leemon that's helpful mance our next question
chapters.title: Do mirror nodes need constant human intervention?

chapters.text: is on one of my favorite use cases the coupon bureau and can you share any more about when the coupon bureau will be going live and what their transactions might look like on the network yeah so for those that don't know about the coupon bureau it's an organization that is working with the largest consumer packaged goods manufacturers in north america to update the way coupons are are managed and they're using hedera to provide that layer of trust so that all of the different participants in sort of the supply chain of coupons have transparency into the coupons and how they're being used and the fact that they're used it reduces fraud increases efficiencies uh it's it's a really cool use case so they are going live the first retailer i should say is going live on february 1st is my understanding that's so that's when we'll start to see some of the redemptions happening i suspect and believe that we should already be seeing main net transactions from certain brands that are registering their coupons i think that's happening today we'll start seeing retailers uh come online uh over the coming weeks and months and we um you know i i believe they expect to be on boarding some pretty large tier ones as well during that time so uh i don't know exactly what those transaction rates are going to look like in terms of tps but we should start seeing some numbers soon and i think that there have out again there have already been some number of transactions on the network as they set up the database thanks mance and we have a note from jay johnson from the coupon bureau um who notes that the demo is feb 15th um so thank you jay all right leemon is there a threat of attack by

chapters.text: manipulating the time protocol and or the servers no so let's talk about this um this is really interesting so imagine first of all in the consensus we use time stamps right you take the median time stamp on an event and that's what we use to put them in order within a round and then that gives you your time stamp and it's a fair time stamp and it's really cool for fairness you need most of the computers having sort of accurate times roughly but what would happen if an attacker could completely control the clock on every computer in the network so every time the computer asked its clock what time is it the attacker could make it always say zero it's always time zero for everybody or he could make it be random and say well first i say it's time zero then i say it's a million years from now then i say it's a million years ago and it's random every time i ask it is it even an order if i ask at the time several times in a row it doesn't even give me answers in order or maybe the attacker makes every computer in the in the entire network always agree that we're in the middle of the middle ages and it's you know a long time ago or we're a million years in the future um not sure we have enough bits actually for that but you know convinces everybody that's 1970 right now would that hurt us in any way it would have zero effect on the speed at which we get consensus and the uh consensus of our consensus you know we're all going to get the same answer so what will happen in any of those attack scenarios is that when you submit a transaction it will still reach consensus just as fast as it always has we will still put them into consensus order the consensus order will still be um uniform across all of us we all agree all the nodes agree you can still trust it the network will be just blazing ahead just the way it always has there are no problems at all you will of course i would assume start getting some nonsense times you know you'll start seeing like my transaction happen in the year one million or whatever uh because of course if all the clocks are wrong how would it know what the time is but you'll still have a guarantee that all the nodes agree on the time of each transaction and that every transaction has an official consensus timestamp that is later than the one before it they will always be in order even if the clocks give you numbers out of order on every single computer the transactions themselves will have times in order and so we have very strong guarantees about that we even have a low resolution fairness if you submit your transaction and then three seconds later it has consensus and then i submit my transaction mine will definitely come later than yours in the consensus order so you know with a three three second uh resolution we even have sort of like fairness what you lose is the fine grain fairness the fine brain fairness says if my transaction reaches all the nodes in the network or most of the nodes in the network a little bit later than yours even a tiny bit later yours should count as coming first and that fine-grained transaction fairness is what you would lose if we didn't have clocks and that's why we used clocks in the protocol but the protocol itself the hashgraph algorithm would work absolutely fine if you got rid of clocks in every entirely and just set the clock on every computer to always be zero and just ignore the clocks so i'm not worried about attacks now the other good news is that if most of the nodes more than two-thirds of the nodes are honest and they're doing their best to get the right time but you know some clocks are a little bit fast and some are a little bit slow and some are a little bit off what kind of a time do we get because we're taking the median it kind of averages out all the errors and so you'll actually find in that scenario that the consensus time stamp is more accurate than any single computer's clock that would be what you would expect and so on average if you were to ask one computer when did this no this message reach most of the nodes if it could actually spy on all the nodes it would even be less accurate than what we get from hedera because hedera has used the meaning of all those clocks so this is this is great we don't need the time protocol consensus works fine without it but if you care about the time stamps like you have a legal contract that says it has to be done by noon on tuesday then our timestamps are very reliable and they give you low resolution fairness automatically but if you have even roughly good clocks they give you high resolution fairness so that's what we've had with the time stems all right thank you leemon mance next one is on council members

chapters.text: smart contract execution um aren't on chain smart contracts a critical part of d5 and gaming and other applications ah great question because um logic is a great part of those but there's multiple ways to do logic so we do smart contracts but we have other ways too so smart contracts have been there from the beginning they're still here they still do exactly what they did on day one there's nothing wrong with them they haven't broken and you can still use them just like you could in the beginning and lots of ledgers have smart contracts and you can use them for lots of purposes and so maybe there are use cases where you would want to use our smart contracts and you can do it but it is inherently the case that smart contracts end up having to run serially they end up having to run on every node in the network and there is a limit to how fast you can do that when every node is doing the computation and it is being done serially there are also limitations on how much privacy you can have with a smart contract there are some things you could talk start talking about doing with encryption and even homomorphic encryption but that's going to be incredibly slow so so smart contracts are a great tool but they don't do everything and what you really want is a way of doing this logic much much faster than just a vanilla smart contract running on a main net and so what everybody has been doing around the world is finding various ways that you can offload it in a way that still has the trust of the main net and so we have layer two ways of doing things and what hedera has put has has created and um allowed people to do is the consensus service which is better than a typical l2 system in a typical l2 system you do all the computation off on the side and occasionally you update the mainnet on what happened but what we can do is kind of invert that model we can do the computation on this side and keep all the data there but let all the transactions flow through the main net to be put in order now just doing the transactions is incredibly fast if all you're doing is taking your smart contract calls and you're just passing those calls through hedera to have hedera put a time stamp on it and put them in order and be able to cryptographically prove that it happened that's incredibly fast and so what you do is you use an app net using our consensus service you use the app net to do the actual logic and to store the data and then pass everything through the main net so that you get the trust of the main net on it and so that is sort of a different approach than l2 l2 approaches would also work with us of course you can always use our file system to store some information and update it only occasionally or have a smart contract on us that you only call occasionally to update from some smart contract running on some other network i mean some local private network you can always do that but hcs gives you another way of doing it and so you can run a smart contract on us or you can do traditional l2 systems or you can do the hcs which gives you incredible speed it also gives you privacy in a smart contract as traditionally written you can't have any secrets a smart contract can't know a secret private key that is kept secret because of the nature of how it works but if you're doing this on an app net and you encrypt everything flowing through hedera and the app net is permissioned you can absolutely keep things secret and so you can get some of the benefits of a smart contract that's public with some of the benefits of private code running and so that's what we're doing so it's not that we don't have smart contracts they're not they're not they haven't disappeared they're still here and then as the whole world is building ways of making them better we also have have ways of making them better and we can do them better the same way other people do but we can also do them with the consensus service and so you have a whole range of choices and which one should you use it depends on your application all right choose your own adventure sounds good choose your adventure mance what are some reasons that may

homomorphic encryption and it can be done there's partially homomorphic encryption there's ways of just doing certain operations that you can actually keep secret from the computer that's running it and you can always do that but if you want to run a general purpose program like an ordinary smart contract you want to take an arbitrary smart contract in any language and be able to run it in other words if you want it to be turing complete which means you can do anything then you'd have to use fully homomorphic encryption to keep it a secret from the computer that's running it and if you want to do that i actually worked on this 20 years ago i was doing research on this um just recently a few years ago someone actually invented it and actually got it working it was immensely exciting i'm really excited about fully homologous encryption however to run an ordinary little smart contract call would take many many hours or days or months even on as on a computer to do it in a fully homomorphic way no one knows how to do that practically right now now there are ways of encrypting databases where you can do just a certain number of operations and still hide it from the person running the database in the computer running the database or there are ways of doing just certain operations like that but if you want to run general purpose programs and you want to keep it secret hcs for that uh you could talk about doing partial versions of that at the native layer of hedera but it will never be able to run fully general programs until we have fully homomorphic encryption coins they could theoretically get a third but they would have to buy up all the coins or you know a third of the coins in existence and in order to do that they have to go out and start buying but the very active buying makes the price go up so the price doesn't have to be high today the price just has to be such that we believe it would go up a lot if someone tried to corner the market on it and then the cost to corner the market on it has to be balanced against um how much profit they're going to make from this scam and so you know if they can only make a million dollars on the scam then it better not cost them more than a million dollars to buy a third otherwise they just won't do it uh and so you'd have to find a scam that they could make a lot of money so much so that it's worth risking it by spending less than that amount of money to corner the market on h bars that sounds hard even today um that sounds hard to do and we haven't even released many of the coins but you know even today i think it would be extremely hard to corner the market on each bars for one person to buy all the hbars so that's what we're talking about um it would appear that that hvars and even other tokens out there would be hard to go buy up a third of them right now so hopefully that will continue to be the case or become even more the case yeah i'm just going to piggyback on that for just a moment the network is secure as long as the nodes are permissioned and that doesn't mean it can be restricted or has to be restricted just to the governing council notes there can be thousands of permissions nodes and the network would be secure independent of of the whole topic that leemon just addressed yeah so we're totally secure as long as we're permissioned we're also totally secure before we've even given away a third of the coins because then no one could get a third of the coins and then even when we get away all the coins and we're not permissioned we're still secure if it's harder to get a third of them you know you cost you more to get a third of them than it would that you would make on your scam so multiple levels of security there and i'm sorry just one more clarification when when we talk about permission we're not talking about people for getting you know going through kyc to create an account on the network we're talking about the nodes that are uh participating in consensus as long as those are permissioned then then we're secure yeah i heard someone understand recently thinking that you had to be permission and do kyc to get an account on hedera that's not true you get it totally anonymously and there's even places you can get it for free um many of the wallets will actually create an account for you for free and totally anonymously now we just like writing notes all right let's see if we can squeeze in one maybe two more here mance what's the right way for a service

chapters.title: Thanks and closing

entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our ninth Town Hall.

Timestamps for this video:
0:00 Intro
1:45 Leemon Baird addresses transaction prices on the Hedera Hashgraph mainnet.
3:15 Is Hedera Hashgraph a good fit for CBDC creation?
7:15 Do mirror nodes need constant human intervention?
10:08 When will The Coupon Bureau go live and what will their transactions look like?
12:04 Is there a threat of attack by manipulating the time protocol and/or the servers?
16:39 Do Hedera Governing Council members share applications that they develop between themselves?
18:49 Why shift away from on-chain smart contract execution?
22:40 What are some reasons that may delay future Hedera Governing Council members' readiness to announce their membership?
28:22 Will Hedera Hashgraph be part of the future world monetary system? 
29:59 Where is the Hedera daily transaction increase coming from?
31:32 Would Hedera Hashgraph prevented the recent Russian hacking (SolarWinds)?
34:58 How is Hedera Hashgraph ready to be part of the global digitization?
37:43 What will Hedera Hashgraph look like in the future?
39:59 What are the competitive advantages Hedera has compared to all other DLTs?
42:34 A clarification on the HBAR token release schedule.
44:10 Will sovereign nations be for, against or neutral about running their digital currencies on Hedera?
46:11 Did Jordan Fried leave on good terms?
47:10 Do Hedera Governing Council members, operating as nodes, have access to information that is different compared to non-governing nodes?
48:26 Are the Hedera Governing Council members willing and able to pivot their business models due to hashgraph's disruptive features?
50:06 A clarification on the relationship between network security and the price of HBAR.
53:28 How can a service provider offer proof that anonymous data gets stored safely and what service would best suit this purpose?
54:26 Can blockchain be used to certify and secure IP rights in lieu of patents or copyrights?
55:37 Thanks and closing

Developer resources:
Chat: https://hedera.com/discord
Docs: https://docs.hedera.com/guides
GitHub: https://github.com/hashgraph
Testnet Access: https://portal.hedera.com

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hedera
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://hedera.com/discord
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Whitepapers: https://hedera.com/papers

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | January 2021

chapters.text: welcome to our eighth monthly hedera town hall we are so glad to have you guys and it is as leemon said great to always have such wonderful representation and hear from people from all over the world it helps us i know personally feel a little bit more connected with our community during this time when we can't actually see your smiling faces in person um so we've got a lot to get through today i will go ahead and jump in mance this first question is on hedera's vision and we you know hedera has been looking
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: at enterprise use cases to reach users and have better adoption however i'm not sure what's stopping the adoption of a hybrid approach to reach out to community users directly via d5 or decks and other projects and ultimately dlt should be for the people not just from the technology perspective but by the very definition of the word distributed yeah well look thank you for the question uh to kick things off here so i agree with the principle outlined here and i would refine it in the following way when we choose what to develop for the platform we are choosing features that can be used to enable a large a large range of products not just a single product typically i mean we are a platform in that sense it's meant to be horizontal to be able to support lots of different use cases while we don't tend to directly develop products in any specific vertical we understand that the community will develop products in many verticals including defy and i do have first-hand knowledge of multiple projects in the market that are doing exactly that so i think it's fair to say that they will be making announcements as those projects mature uh but as an organization what we're not focused on is a single vertical but enabling the community at large to do the kinds of things that they want to do including the ones that you've you've just raised in this question so stay tuned all right thanks mance and the next one i think is top of a lot of people's minds leemon so we wanted to address it up early on in the call i would it have been possible to have the u.s
chapters.title: How can Hedera reach out to community users directly via DeFi or DEX?

chapters.text: presidential election voting on a distributed ledger or are there still a lot of cons to using dlt for voting and looking at some of the things online it seems like we're still a long ways away from having trusted and impartial voting on a distributed ledger oh you're right so um there are ways that ledgers could be used in the voting process and eventually it could be used in a lot of ways but there's a lot of things we have to do first so we're not ready as a society to be doing this and here's just some of the things to think about in the complexity of the security here you can imagine that maybe each local precinct stores a hash of their votes on the network just so that they can't later change it without saying it you could use something like that right today but it doesn't bring a whole lot of value but it has some value for auditing to prevent you from telling two different people two different answers or changing your answers after the fact you could do that today but what you're really thinking about is you know having our whole voting system i just push a button on my phone and i vote and it's on a ledger and it's unchangeable and we can trust it right there's a lot of problems with that there was even a publication from mit i saw recently explaining a lot of the different problems but there's a huge number of problems with that and we'll get there but not today so to do something like that here's just some of the issues you have to worry about we need a good identity system which at a bare minimum in the united states would mean that you need to have the um driver's license being issued by the government on ledger you need to have the social security card being issued on a ledger you need to make sure the important thing is that if you move out of a state you get removed from the voter rolls from that state or if you leave the country or a deceased or any of the different ways you could leave the system you have to make sure that that gets updated in the identity system so it can't just be an identity system for a piece of the country you'd have to have absolutely everyone in the country in an electronic identity system that is updated and guaranteed and and you'd want that to be on the ledger or or the ledger be able to read that and know that it's getting the truth so just there just even before we can start you have to do that then you have to make sure that voter registration is secure then you have to make sure that the software is secure and this bothers me right now in places that use electronic voting machines which is pretty common what if there's a bug in the software lots of hackers hacked into such machines now at the moment i'm not aware of any particular bugs in the machines that are in use but there are there have been concerns a lot of these machines will spit out a receipt a paper receipt and that we can later count those that's a good idea what you want is maybe it prints two receipts and one goes to the user and one goes to the to a bucket that holds them that we can count if we need to or something there's there's lots of yeah but you have to print them at the same time if the printer prints one and then prints the other you can hack it so it prints different things so you want to use carbon paper or carbonless paper to do them both at once so you want to do something like that and then there's the question of what how do you actually know that your vote was counted correctly but maintain privacy so people like chomp have invented all sorts of cool math to do this where they give you a receipt at the at the election that looks funny and you can later check online and it shows you something on the screen that looks funny on your computer screen but then you take this clear plastic with black squares at you as your receipt and you put it over the screen and you can see how you voted and see if it was recorded correctly there's lots of really crazy things like that that you can do and then you have the problem of bugs in the software if you're gonna vote from your phone you want that's really far away at a bare minimum you need to have the program have a math proof that it is correct that can be checked by a computer proof carrying code it needs to go into a secure chip in your phone not your normal phone chip and that secure chip in the phone has to be able to show you who you can vote for and let you vote on a separate screen maybe on the back of the phone that has an ok button that's just connected to that special chip it has its own special operating system and the main phone only connects through a um a serial connection that's very carefully locked down that whole architecture can be done but nobody's doing that yet uh and that's something we're gonna need for real true security and then you still have the problem of what if somebody is watching you vote and paying you while you're voting to vote for for somebody or maybe they pay you to give them your phone and then they can vote on election day for you how do you stop that i don't know that's actually a really hard problem so voting is a very complex thing auditing we can do today and maybe there's some value to that um but uh but our current system is is pretty secure and you don't want to go to a system that's worse and occasionally one precinct will make a mistake and that affects a few votes but if you go to a system wherever the country is running one piece of software you make a mistake in that software then it affects everyone in the country and that's not as good so we want to be very careful we have a good system we don't want to make it worse and we have to go very step by step but we'll do that eventually all right thank you leemon um mance has anyone used the hedera token service yet
chapters.title: Was it possible to have the US Presidential election voting managed on a distributed ledger or is DLT not ready for such a use case?

chapters.text: and are any uh interested parties considering it right so the short answer is yes we are building the hedera token service in response to market demand so most of this year has been spent determining which use cases are the most important to the market uh we started off with a dozen and we've narrowed it down to a couple tokenization generally speaking including the hts as well as data integrity um we did that in part by looking at how the network was being used and also by just listening to the customers that we were talking to so it became clear at the beginning of the summer that there was a large pinup demand for tokenization services on hedera generally and that takes two forms there's the ability to create a fully customized token of any flavor you can imagine using hcs and an app net the app net of course would be holding the ledger itself and hcs would do uh put put the transactions into consensus order and then in addition to that what you all have seen on the preview net and is coming is hts today tokenization service that makes it possible for users to very quickly spin up an erc 20 like token you know it's it's not an erc20 it's our own specification but it's it's very quick and easy with less customization opportunity that as you would have in if you were using hcs so we have customers in various stages of uh development and interest for both of those so again the simple answer is yes all right thanks for the update vance leemon we have a question here from a
chapters.title: Has anyone used Hedera Token Service yet?

chapters.text: web developer slash e-commerce store creator how can i utilize hedera there was once a wordpress plugin any updates yeah so we do a lot of these demo things and release the source code so that you can build it so feel free build such a thing that's really cool you can use our wordpress plugin that we wrote as an example a long time ago use that code uh it's not a product it's not something that we're you know we're developing and making changes to it and so on it was a demo that we wrote and we released and so go ahead and use the source code download and use it and modify it and fix it and whatever and we do a lot of these and we would encourage you to go ahead and play with them build something if you want to build something and give it away open source if you want to get a bunch of people and build a whole project around it or build a company around it and that'd be cool and i know some people have done that uh with um with e-commerce and uh you know paying to see things on web pages and if you want to do that too that'd be very cool all right man's next one is for you are you planning to provide financial
chapters.title: How can a web developer use Hedera?

chapters.text: support for startups who are building on hedera besides the technical support provided by the boost program right so uh another great question and this is uh this is one i've been looking forward to answering so leemon and i are both directly working on a program that is designed to incentivize the growth of the hedera ecosystem generally so rather than exclusively focusing on transactions per second we're going to incentivize the creation of active accounts what we're calling active accounts meaning accounts that have a non-trivial balance of hbar in them over a period of time as well as the creation of a large well let's stick with active accounts so if we create a large population of active accounts then that base of active accounts represents a market for any dapps or applications that would potentially build on top of the hedera platform so we're we're going to incentivize specifically the creation of active accounts in addition the flip side of that coin is that we're going to incentivize applications to provide hbar holders something to do with their hbar outside of making api calls on the network itself so we are focused on transactions per second the creation of active accounts as well as incentivizing applications to provide hbar holders to do something with the hbar outside of merely making api calls on the platform in other words we're building a program that will incentivize the growth of a decentralized economic ecosystem that's that's the goal here right so this is different than simply paying a large staking reward that would incentivize people to lock up their tokens until the rewards end that's not what we're talking about here on the contrary we're focused on providing incentives that lead to a sustained lasting ecosystem that's the goal we're now working with our first few grant recipients on the details of this and we will be providing more information as the program matures you know that reminds me you mentioned we're incentivizing people who will drive tps who create active accounts real accounts with different people owning them and will um give you things to do with hbar on the network i love those three we don't care about fake accounts or empty accounts or a million accounts owned by one person and it reminds me of what happened this weekend did you guys see that it was kind of funny ah sad but um there was somebody who set up a website to create free accounts for you he would pay for it the guy set up the website would pay for you to create an account and it's a great thing he was being generous and and you know whenever someone's generous other people tend to want to take advantage of it and i hate that and so somebody wrote a bot that created lots and lots of accounts and he ended up losing a couple hundred dollars before he turned it off which was sad it doesn't hurt the network doesn't affect us but it's just sad to see that happen to somebody and i was just thinking what's the moral of the story is it you should never be generous no being generous is a good thing what i would say is if you want to be generous be generous that's a good thing but when you write your software put a cap that you'll only be generous so many times per day and that way if someone tries to take advantage of you you'll know it and they just don't take advantage of you very much um so that was unfortunate and that happened over the weekend you may have noticed a whole bunch of accounts got created and then on monday more accounts were being created but this was by a legitimate person so i think it may even still be going on right now but they're just creating lots of accounts and that's also a legitimate person and so we don't mind either of those two but they don't particularly help us either and so we're not incentivizing those if we want to incentivize accounts it'll be real accounts where every account is owned by a separate person and has a lot of hvars in it then they become potential customers for other companies to come into the ecosystem and it builds the ecosystem we want to reward that but these these current things are just creating a whole bunch of accounts you know doesn't hurt us but it doesn't help us so we're not going to reward that all right thank you both um leemon hedera is a public network so it's
chapters.title: Will Hedera provide financial support to startups?

chapters.text: accessible to anyone when sharding is available is it possible for a specific shard on the network to be permissioned and private and communicate with public shards only as necessary absolutely and it's not shards it's app nets shards almost by definition are all the same and they're public and they can't be private but app nets are private it's exactly what you're describing you can do that today and we have software to help you do that and we have a bunch of blogs and things telling you about how to do that you can set up your own permissioned private network everything is encrypted only people can come to it who you invite you can or you can do kyc or you can have gatekeeping or you can charge people to join your game or whatever you want to do you can make it as private as you want and then what you do is you encrypt all your messages and you send them through hedera and so basically all the transactions on your private network go through hedera and so you have all the trust of hedera in what order they put in and what time stamps you put on them but you can encrypt them so you have total privacy and then within your little closed ecosystem you do whatever you want um that's that's a beautiful thing that you can do with hcs and so yes we do exactly what you're describing today it's not called shards it's called appnets it's the hedera consensus service great thanks for clarifying that leemon mance can you tell us more about the
chapters.title: Is it possible for a specific shard on the network be permissioned and private?

chapters.text: monthly payments that hedera makes to swirls yeah sure so um look first off we pride ourselves on being as transparent as possible we have given full disclosures on the relationship between swirls and hedera rather than spending this time going through all of that what we're going to do here is post a link to a blog that has all of that information zenobia are you posting it or should i uh if you can i for some reason don't have access to the chat right now okay so i will post that link um while leemon answers the next question but but uh happy to disclose that we have disclosed all of it it's out there i'm going to give you a link and go take a look all right thanks mance um leemon more interest in appnets um so what implications would a cbdc
chapters.title: Details on the monthly payments Hedera pays to Swirlds.

chapters.text: based on a private permissioned app net run by centralized servers of central banks have on the promises of hedera being open and secure for any participants and then i'll go ahead and keep asking the rest of this question but i can repeat it and if you need afterwards could central instances of such app nets block certain accounts from transacting on their appnet could governments force hedera to block certain topics and thereby prevent unwanted appnets from using hcs on the mainnet how open and free can hedera be when it comes to private permissioned app nets great question and it's really the same answer as the previous one if you want to set up a private permissioned app net or if a government wants to set up a private permissioned app net then you can control whatever it does you can filter it out you can you know if you want to stop people from using it or shut down accounts or spy on people or steal or whatever you want to do you set up the rules it's entirely up to you how you set up your app net as for hedera we're just a carrier we're just like a telephone system you send us transactions and we send them back to you in order we're not going to block the topic we're not going to shut down your ability to feed a stream of transactions through us and if you encrypt them we can't even read your transactions we can't even spy on you we're just all we do is put them in order for you and so we have not written the software to allow us to delete a topic or freeze a topic or filter a topic um a topic doesn't store any information it's just a conduit it's just a pipe and we provide the pipes and if you want to create a totally open app net you can do that if you want to have one that's all closed and controlled you can do that you can do whatever you want you're building on top of us but we are simply open that's what we are all right thanks leemon um mance uh question on the governing
chapters.title: What implications would a CBDC based on a private permissioned appnet, run by centralized servers or central banks, have on the promises of Hedera being open and secure for all participants?

chapters.text: council um what are the chances of a mass exit of governing council members just like what happened with libra are there any instances to curb any measures to curb such instances well so i think that the chance of a mass exodus is very low first we've taken a very conservative regulatory approach from the beginning we understand that our council members care about being circumspect as it you know as it relates to the regulatory environment and they're not interested in participating in an organization that would put their interests at risk so we don't and the choices that we make minimize the risk on behalf of our members that's the way we've done it from the very beginning second the interests of our council members are aligned uh our members are a mix of those that provide cloud infrastructure consulting and professional services and those that have specific use cases that they'd like to build and deploy so the choice of council members was designed from the beginning to be synergistic so we just don't have uh the the the motivations for council members to depart in uh in a in a way where a bunch of them would be doing so at once great thank you man okay leemon um let's talk a little bit about security
chapters.title: What are the chances of a mass exit of Governing Council Members?

chapters.text: and given that security of the network in part depends on a high price for hbar and without you know going into details that would be malicious actors could use what can you say to network users about measures that hedera has in place to protect against attacks on the price of hr oh so to begin with we're totally safe right now because we don't have anonymous nodes so there's no fear that there'll be a civil attack where someone creates lots of anonymous nodes and uses all those h bars to hurt us because there are no anonymous notes right now and we may do that someday and we'll only do it if we're convinced that the h bars are spread out widely enough and that you don't have all of them owned by one person so that's exactly the thing that we will be looking at and we will not go to anonymous nodes until we're sure it's secure but right now we don't have anonymous nodes and so it's not an issue um also we have released less than a third of the h bars and as long as less than a third have been released it's impossible for an attacker to get a third of the hbars so the the problem you're describing is a real issue that we're concerned about in the future and we will not take a step that is dangerous unless we are convinced that this isn't a problem but that's in the future for right now we're safe two different ways uh regardless you know even if all the released hvars were held by one person it wouldn't hurt us all right thanks leemon um okay man it's another one on the governing council for
chapters.title: What measures does Hedera have in place to protect against attacks?

chapters.text: you are all the governing council members actively uh building use cases of their own uh does hedera have enough manpower to support the development and training activities of these governing council members so different council members do different things they have different uh motivations for being on the council so i i would not say that every single council member is building an application though i don't believe that's the case but a number of them are you're right in the assumption that it's not possible for hedera to have enough manpower to support everything that's going on so we have to do two things we prioritize the the high touch accounts that's what we would call them the accounts that we're working with directly in directly supporting with our own resources we prioritize them based on tps active account creation and what we're calling sort of value creation the the opportunity to realize additional things for h-bar holders to do with their h-bars we prioritize those and then there are a large number of other opportunities that we don't personally support or touch we do that through system integrators and the list of system integrators that are supporting hedera with their with their resources and their service is growing wipro for example is a council member that falls into that category so wipro does provide consulting services for hedera projects as an example but it's not it's not restricted to just council members that are consultancies that provide those services there are other there's a whole channel of system integrators both large and small that is being developed that are building practices around the support of hedera projects that's how we scale we're not going to be a big company we're never going to be a large organization in terms of people we're scaling the efforts through the creation of a channel through the system integrators all right thanks mance um the next one is uh related to some coupon bureau
chapters.title: Are all Governing Council Members actively building use cases of their own?

next one is on hbar uh in previous town halls uh

chapters.text: you have explained that hbar is not a security but is a utility token what is the benefit to that as as to why hedera has chosen um hbar to be a utility token yeah so let me first start by just sort of correcting a misperception hedera didn't choose whether it's a security or or not um we we don't have the authority to choose whether it's one or the other what our view is is that based on the facts and circumstances the sale of hbars and transactions and h-bars should not be subject to u.s securities laws we meaning it's not a security or it's our belief it's not a security we structured it to not be a security we believe that we have a strong basis for that position but ultimately it's going to be a legal determination on the part of the regulators that's not true just for us it's true for every platform in the market and it doesn't really matter what our view is it's the view of the regulators that count now if it's a security then there are a whole set of laws that apply to it that would have an impact on its use in the way that the platform has been designed to use you know hbars but we you know we're confident in our view we've been in discussion with regulators for years now a couple at least a couple years maybe longer and um and and so that's that those are the implications and and that's a little bit of clarification on on our position in addition there is a blog i'm going to share this blog with the community here as well that can go and or does go in more depth and and will give you more information on that all right thanks mance um our next question comes from someone with a very
chapters.title: HBAR clarification on security vs utility token status.

chapters.text: long-term view leemon um you have said you plan on being a hundred-year company why would you limit hedera to 100 years i love the way you think no no what we always meant is at least 100 years what we're saying is you want this company to be something real that provides a utility to the planet forever indefinitely you know at least a hundred years is the way they were saying that as opposed to just make a quick buck do it pump and dump and have it go away in a year we went to last generations we wanted to last throughout history this is the goal is to build something real that will be providing a real benefit to humanity forever this is the goal um and so um yes i would never limit it to a mere 100 years that would be terrible all right good good um okay mance something a little bit more um specific and of our time um in the latest council minutes
