chapters.text: uh it was noted that a council member expressed his views on recent lawsuits enforcement actions fundraising strategies and overall activities in the dlt space and how hedera's conservative regulatory stance and restrictions on certain activities may be hampering its position in the market can you elaborate a bit more as to what specifically he was referring to yeah so uh thank you again for the question i want to add some clarity to this the member when commenting on recent lawsuits enforcement actions fundraising strategies and overall activities those were not referring to anything related to hedera those the member was talking about in the industry in the distributed ledger industry there have been enforcement actions fundraising you know various fundraising strategies overall activities etc so it's not the case that they were talking specifically about something that we have done in in the context of this uh the sentence here however they did raise the question of whether hedera is being too conservative in our regulatory stance and our restrictions on certain activities we're pretty conservative and in what we will and will not do one of the features and challenges of decentralized governance is that we have numerous members with different risk profiles different perspectives that operate in different jurisdictions uh so it's not the case that uh there you know that they all have the same opinions and same same views on on anything right and just about any any decision that has to be made that's consequential uh there there's a lot of debate that goes on i view that as a very healthy thing so i would say that it's an ongoing discussion it's an ongoing conversation about how to balance business needs against a whole variety of risks market risks regulatory risks etc and it is a conversation that's worth revisiting regularly regularly and we do so so um you know it came up again in in the last council meeting it will probably come up in most council meetings as we continue to monitor the environment including the regulatory environment and we make decisions that affect all the council members in hedera as a whole all right thank you mance leemon how can we as the community help spread

chapters.text: the word about hedera oh yeah so you can tell your friends you can give you can tell other people you can give people links to it or whatever you can have meetups and things but you can also build things on us and if you start to build projects in this ecosystem you can interact with other people in the ecosystem build projects you can build an open source thing and release it or you can get with a group of people and build something bigger maybe open source and release it or not or you can build a whole company that is in this ecosystem and we are talking lots of little startup companies that are just you know a person in their garage or several people in a garage and um and it's exciting and so do that um and if you aren't interested in any of those things then just tell people about us and uh and give them links to our various videos and blogs and podcasts and all that stuff this this very video uh but i really appreciate uh the all of the interest that we have we have a huge number of people that are telling about it and evangelizing about it and um and building on it and playing as part of this ecosystem and so i just want to say thank you to all of you doing that all right great mance can hedera reach out to
chapters.title: How can the community help spread the word about Hedera?

chapters.text: pfizer or any of the other um you know vaccine makers in any way to assist with the vital task of rolling out their vaccine and or is anyone who's closely partnered with hedera such as acor willing and able to add value to the effort to get as many people vaccinated as soon as possible yeah well look i'm i'm proud to say that safe health systems slash acor are working with premium partners to directly address the needs created by covid in addition there are industry working groups being formed that not only address the immediate needs of tracking the status of covid vaccinations but their goal is to modernize the entire global system for tracking immunizations generally i've personally had the opportunity to participate in the kickoff of some of those discussions and i consider it a privilege for safe health and hedera to be able to contribute to those efforts so the answer is yes and we are and more will be more will be coming out in the in the future about those efforts all right great thank you mance um okay i'm gonna take the next one as it

entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our eighth Town Hall. Topics ranged from the possibility of using a DLT to vote on the U.S. presidential election, the Hedera Token Service, their favorite horror movies, and much more!

Timestamps for this video:
0:00 Intro
0:35 How can Hedera reach out to community users directly via DeFi or DEX?
2:26 Was it possible to have the US Presidential election voting managed on a distributed ledger or is DLT not ready for such a use case?
7:32 Has anyone used Hedera Token Service yet?
9:27 How can a web developer use Hedera?
10:30 Will Hedera provide financial support to startups?
14:53 Is it possible for a specific shard on the network be permissioned and private?
16:14 Details on the monthly payments Hedera pays to Swirlds.
https://hedera.com/blog/hedera-january-update-on-business-operations-and-saft-amendment-proposal
https://help.hedera.com/hc/en-us/articles/360006895498-What-are-the-material-financial-terms-of-the-license-agreement-between-Hedera-and-Swirlds-
17:13 What implications would a CBDC based on a private permissioned appnet, run by centralized servers or central banks, have on the promises of Hedera being open and secure for all participants?
19:12 What are the chances of a mass exit of Governing Council Members? 
20:36 What measures does Hedera have in place to protect against attacks?
22:07 Are all Governing Council Members actively building use cases of their own?
24:32 An update on The Coupon Bureau
27:35 HBAR clarification on security vs utility token status.
https://help.hedera.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002542738-Will-regulators-deem-hbars-to-be-securities-#breadcrumb
29:44 Why limit Hedera to only a 100-year company?
30:42 Comments on Hedera's conservative regulatory stance and restrictions on certain activities that might be hampering its position in the market. 
33:25 How can the community help spread the word about Hedera?
34:33 Can Hedera support Pfizer (or any vaccine producer) to assist with rolling out the vaccine?
35:50 What is Hedera's view on leveraging social media influencers to support marketing efforts?
37:22 What other names were considered other than Hedera?
38:21 If Mance or Leemon could live their lives a second time, what passion or field would they pursue outside of DLT?
41:36 What is Leemon's preferred news source?
42:54 If Leemon could discuss only one topic with Elon Musk, what would it be?
45:55 What kind of community can Leemon envision living in if he were to retire to Mars?
47:46 Favorite horror movies?
49:37 When to submit questions and check the FAQ - https://help.hedera.com/
50:54 Hala Systems seeks justice with tamper-proof evidence on Hedera Consensus Service

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hashgraph
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://hedera.com/discord
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Whitepapers: https://hedera.com/papers

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

chapters.text: hashgraph algorithm were created out of your vision for share worlds shared worlds can you paint a picture for us of what these shared worlds would look like in virtual reality or augmented reality and would it have any resemblance to ready player one and if so who would you be in such a universe um uh yeah someone asked me what are you doing rpgs or they said d and d i don't play i haven't played dvd but rpgs i usually do the magic guys because that's that's a lot like computer science um but would it look like ready player one short answer is yes so i do think that we are coming i'm really i really am interested in vr and in 3d graphics um especially 3d graphic algorithms and we can talk about fractals and things sometime very exciting stuff i've done work in that uh so yes in some sense we're going to have a future where you have vr like you see in ready player one and you can see in snow crash you can see in tron and you know literature is full of and movies are full of these vr worlds that they show and augmented too but but vr is in some ways more exciting however did you notice that most of those from snow crash to ready player one envisioned that the entire vo world is living on one computer controlled by one person or i think in tron it was one program yeah i think that's true um and that's not decentralized and i think the future really is going to be decentralized the world of cyberspace and vr is not going to be like a website it's going to be like the web lots of websites with links between them and each one run by different people and you will have centralized servers running web worlds you know like second life or whatever you will have that that will happen but you're also going to have the more interesting shared worlds that are decentralized and i think that there's a lot of advantages to having a decentralized world no one computer can crash and take it down no one person is the dictator of the universe that can control everything in the universe you have true trust in it and and of course if you're doing anything like buying and selling things you really want that but even just for games and for having fun it'd be nice to have a world where i know that rules are enforced there might be anti-griefing rules like each player is allowed to take its section of the world and call it theirs and then no one else is able to change things in that section and that rule would be enforced and there'd be no ruler that enforces it i guess minecraft has things called anarchy servers where they claim that there is no rules and no one in charge and yet you find out in the anarchy servers yeah people are actually in charge and they come in and change things sometimes um you could have decentralized worlds where that can never happen and so that is where we're going to go and it will look like these things like uh ready player one except you're going to have hyperlinks and when you touch a hyperlink you go somewhere else in the same world or even to a different world run on a different ledger by different people with different rules but then you need the most important thing that the web has your web browser has that little lock icon up at the top to tell you i think i went to google.com did i really go to google.com or i'm going to something else is there a guy in the middle a man in the middle uh attacking me and so what you do is you need have that little lock that says nope if it i am truly at the real google.com well we'd have the same thing if this is a shared world run on top of hedera you'd have a little lock saying this is truly the shared world run by hedera but that lock how does that come about on the web it's because the one person ruling that website has a public key and they've registered it in various ways but in a decentralized ledger you don't have that the only way to do it is state proofs and so i think truly the future of the vr is going to be a world a cosmos full of decentralized worlds and the only way that you can know for sure and have any trust is that you have state proofs so that when you follow a hyperlink and go to a world you don't have to download its blockchain back to the genesis to know that it's real you can just get a state proof that proves that it's real and it really is them so i am very excited about that i have a quest which i think is great i've owned a whole bunch of vr sets and i've given them all away and now i'm just down to the quest because the quest is wireless which i just think is wonderful and it's wired which chapters.text: it's hashgraph's use of a median wall clock time as part of as a core part of consensus vulnerable to skewing if so could that mess up consensus no it can't so let's go through this this is really cool i'm not even sure i've talked about this in in talks before so it uses the the clocks in order to ensure fairness and and it uses it in the algorithm however the algorithm is abft no matter what the clocks do so imagine that every computer had a clock that just always returns zero it says the current time is zero which is like 1970 or something um everything still works we still get consensus we still are abft everything works or suppose every clock in every computer was completely random every time you asked it what time it was you got a random number and so half the time it's running backwards still works perfectly you still get consensus just as fast no problems or suppose even worse an attacker a single attacker could magically control the clock in every single computer on the network in that case still works we will still come to consensus the consensus can't be prevented by this attacker we all come to the same consensus we come to consensus just as fast as we did when we had real clocks um these these attacked clocks don't slow down our consensus we can do just as many transactions per second what we lose is fairness in fact what we lose is the high resolution fairness that we're proud of we would still have a low resolution fairness if you submit a transaction and then it comes to consensus takes a few seconds and then i submit a transaction mine will count as later than yours so we do have that kind of low resolution fairness but when the clocks are being attacked if all the clocks are attacked then it is possible that you and i could send out our transactions at about the same time yours reaches the whole network before mine reaches the network and yet mine would count as being before you so that would be the the bad thing that would happen is that um we would have um uh we would not have that fairness anymore if an attacker were controlling all of our clocks however in the real world an attacker is unlikely to control all the clocks they're more likely to control just the clocks than the computers they control which means less than a third we assume that less than a third are malicious you know if a lot of computers more than a third or a third are malicious then we have problems but as long as less than a third are malicious you can guarantee that not only are we avft we come to conclusion to consensus fast but it is fair in the sense that you will get a timestamp put onto your transaction a consensus timestamp that is from an honest computer or it's between the two timestamps of honest computers so you have a very good guarantee that these honest computers that have good clocks or roughly good clocks will give you good time stamps or roughly good time stamps even if the attacker tried to say well i received it a million years ago or a million years in the future if they literally said a million years in the past of the future it can't really mess that up very much so it's only if they could control all of our clocks would you start having ridiculously crazy time stamps on our messages on our transactions the consensus time stamps would be kind of bad and we wouldn't have the high resolution fairness that we're so proud of but we'd still come to consensus it'd still be guaranteed it'd still take a few seconds it'd still be a bft it'd still be uncorruptable uh you would never be able to double spend nothing bad would happen as long as you're not looking at those time stamps and relying them on first on them for something um everything is good and in the real world where the bad guys control less than a third of the computers then if the good guys have their compute their clocks all a little bit off we end up taking the median which kind of averages out all the error and so you will actually get a better answer than any single clock would have given you um so that's that's where we are uh it's it's a beautiful part of the algorithm and the most beautiful part of it is that you don't have to have it uh but it's it's just great because it gives us the fairness very cool amen thanks okay mance the next one comes
chapters.title: Is hashgraph's use of a median wall clock time, as a core part of consensus, vulnerable to skewing?

chapters.text: network cancelled oh not canceled now we have an upgrade after tomorrow so um what happened was that we had an upgrade scheduled for a thursday this month we moved it to a later thursday the reason we did that was because we found that there was one rare occasion when one of the computers would slow down compared to the rest if you were doing thousands of transactions a second now of course we could have deployed that to mainnet because we're not currently seeing thousands of transactions a second and if one computer slowed down it wouldn't matter anyway the network is a wholly fast but we're we're really really careful to try to make sure that absolute perfection goes onto mainnet whenever possible and so if it's true that there's a rare case under high load where one computer might slow down we don't want to do it and so we just delayed and so we'll do it after tomorrow and we won't have that issue you know we saw what was doing that we fixed it so we are we do a very strong job of making sure that things are good and so what we do i'll just go through the process is that we are constantly testing our code as you write the code you do unit tests and test it and then every time you commit it to github every time a developer commits to github it gets automatically some more tests run on it and then every night a big set of tests run overnight automatically on all the code and then we manually kick off regression test runs that are long and we do them for longer and longer and then we're convinced the code is pretty good we post it to the preview net and everyone can see it on the preview net and play with it and then when it's run on that for a while and we're convinced that it's more good we deploy it to the public test net the stable test net and it runs there for two weeks before we put it on to the main net and so you could say why did you delay from one thursday early in october to one later in october why not just delay doesn't really matter um and we just keep using 10 because we're used to it in computer science base 2 is really important because everything is binary under the hood and so we like things like base 16 and even base 8 because they relate nicely to base 2. in crypto we don't really use other bases there has been work of just releasing codes in code groups of five digits you could say that was a base but it's not really a base a caesar cipher i guess is a base it works on a base but really even that is not really about a base really what we use in cryptography is modular arithmetic this is like when it's 11 o'clock two hours later it'll be one o'clock eleven plus two is one well it wrapped around we use wrapping around although instead of going from one to twelve we usually go from zero to eleven or zero to something so you could have a system let's say modulo 15 when you add up numbers you always take the answer and wrap it around subtract 15 a bunch of times to get back to a number between 0 and 14. if you add two numbers mod 15 you could have done the mod 15 on each number first before you added them if you multiply them on 15 you could have done it on each one individually before you multiplied them if you divide them you could have done it individually before you divide them although the division is kind of weird in the modular world kind of ignore division if you subtract them you could do it individually if you raised one to another power you could do mod 15 to the base but you don't have the exponent wrap around mod 15. it wraps around mod 8. isn't that weird so we can add subtract multiply and divide divisions weird but adds direct and multiply and everything is mod 15 but when you go into exponents that exponent lives up here in a higher plane a different realm and in this higher world things wrap around base 8 not base 15. how bizarre and you know what you can't even figure out the number 8 unless you know that 15 is 3 times 5. and so if you knew the 15 but you didn't know how to factor it into 3 times five then you wouldn't be able to guess the eight and you wouldn't know how things in the exponent wrap around and you could use that impossibility or that difficulty to build a crypto system like rsa and that's how rsa works because we wrap around but for exponents you don't know how it wraps around until you know the factors of the of the modulus so that's why we make things wrap around in cryptography and then we have fancier things like elliptic curves and they are exactly the same thing but they sort of work similarly in some ways and and you get into abstract algebra rather than number theory and that's really fun so that's what we do in cryptography in normal math we use 10 just because we've always used it we've always used it because of this that's it all right thanks leemon um and i for one would love more cryptography and math questions from this community because i love hearing uh leemon explain them so please keep sending those our way uh leemon one more for you here
chapters.title: What are the benefits of using Base 10 in arithmetic? How are different based arithmetics applied and used in cryptography?

chapters.text: um this one you know i think we have talked a lot about regulatory compliance and it means different things different people so i think this is an opportunity for us to sort of explain some different things we had a question about what it means for hedera to be regulatory compliant and then more specifically if for example a regulation or court order demands the reversal of a transaction would it even be possible for hedera to comply ah yes so let's talk about exactly what this means to lay your fears to rest if there is a cryptocurrency transfer from this account to this account we do not have the ability to undo that transfer and take the money back out of this one and put it in this one we do not have the ability to undo it it is immutably in our in our history now maybe a court could order this person to then send the money back that's possible but if they know who this person is but it has nothing to do with us this person would actually have to sign the transaction to send the hbars back to this account we don't have anything to do with that we have no ability we also can't freeze this account we can't change the keys on this account uh we do not have the ability to go out and manipulate your account we can't freeze it we can't take stuff out of it we can't delete it we have written all the software so that we cannot do it the things we do have to be signed by the council and there is nothing they can sign that would do that we would have to completely change the entire system this has been what we have done from the beginning to be um trustworthy uh so yeah i've even heard of people talking about hey you should build a chain where you can undo things that's a really bad idea what you should do is make sure that the rules are enforced and the rules that we have are that only the person who has the keys to an account can send it we've even gotten emails from people that say um i had my key written down my recovery phrase and i lost it would you mind recovering it for me would you could you email me my my recovery phrase please oh i'm sorry i can't email you your recovery phrase we don't have it and the entire system is built so we can never get it anyway that's um that's what we have built for the trustworthiness of it so what do we mean by regulatory compliant well lots of examples so like the sec the sec has lots of rules on when you do an ipo when you sell stock so what about an ico what are the rules there well like many things maybe there's a lot of ambiguity there who knows what the rules are and we were hyper conservative we never had an ico just because we wanted just in case the scc decided they didn't like it we wouldn't have done it and so wherever the rules have been fuzzy we have been tried to be ultra conservative ultra compliant uh we didn't incorporate in um an island somewhere with low laws lacks laws we incorporate united states we're headquartered united states we have tried to um be as compliant as we can we've talked at the sec all along told them what we're doing we have tried to be above board we have tried to be very careful in everything we do uh whenever we're not sure um about the rules we kind of follow all the rules we say well no matter what you call us we're following the rules we'll follow the rules as if we were a security as if we were commodity and as if we were a currency we'll follow those rules so that we're kind of safe no matter what you think we are that's what we've been doing gdpr we we have controlled mutability for gdpr which says that if the council agrees we can uh delete a file now this is on the mainnet the the histories are stored elsewhere so you still have the file on mirror nodes but for the file that's on the main net we can delete it if we need to so we had the control g uh gdpr controlled mutability for the files to ensure that you know they don't have bad things in them in that sense that's never been exercised but if a court ordered us to we could do that mirror nodes though are out of our control and the mirror nodes are set up to store things forever that's not our control so that's just on main net so basically what we have tried to do is be as compliant as possible while giving a trustworthy network and and as i said if you have an hbar account that you created and you send to another one that your friend created it will never be undone it can never be reversed and we can never freeze the account or delete the account or take hbars out of the account without your knowledge that's that is what we mean when we say that we are compliant thanks leemon for walking us through all that i think there's lots of different areas where that will be applicable and we'll continue to have to take a look at and get questions i'm sure okay mance and the special interest
chapters.title: What does it mean for Hedera to be regulatory complaint? Would it be possible for Hedera to comply with a court ordered cryptocurrency transaction reversal?

chapters.text: groups we have a question is there a sig for synchronization it may not be sexy but organizations large and small are forever struggling to reconcile or synchronize databases so i agree with that 100 percent i think that using hcs as a mechanism to synchronize data stores generally across organizations or even within a large organization that has a lot of business units is a great idea there is not a sig today for that so the we have three we have three sigs that we started with data integrity tokenization and identity those have been meeting for a couple of months now roughly um but you know having a sig for synchronization sounds like a great idea if you want to help start it just send us a note let us know we can explore it and the goal has been from the beginning to have lots of six not just the three but we're starting with the three because there are focus areas for us and we want to learn and make sure that we're getting the sig program right making tweaks here early on and then and then scaling that program so so yeah if you're interested in in being a part or helping to start send us a note we welcome that all right thanks vance lima the next one um okay let's tackle this
chapters.title: Is there a Special Interest Group for synchronization?

chapters.text: why are laws made so difficult to interpret would it not benefit everyone if they were made so simple that even a six-year-old would understand them considering law is supposed to be a very logical field why are we not using ai to decide court cases or an ai lawyer for people who cannot afford another lawyer a computer would be able to find cases to refer to in laws to apply to and would be unbiased yeah so it's back to the natural language understanding problem it's hard to be a lawyer if you can't even read english and understand it that makes lawyerness harder so so here's the bigger problem we could actually write all of our laws in a computer language and then you know the law itself would be readable to a computer but the problem is that our laws often have things like um you must make a best effort to inform your customers of blah blah blah well what's a best effort and if a customer complains well i didn't know that the this giant cereal box only had a little bit of cereal in the bottom you didn't tell me and they said well we put a the max weight of the serial on the box you could read it yeah but i didn't know it's only a quarter full well you could have shaken it and we told you as much as we needed to tell you now does that count as making the best effort to tell them or does it not count as making a best effort to tell them well you've got to take all these things into consideration what exactly did you tell them what exactly were the facts and then what would be a reasonable thing in the mind of a consumer so that if they didn't understand it it was their fault as opposed to if they didn't understand it then you didn't tell them enough so you have to reason about english you have to reason about psychology you have to reason about physics could they have shipped the box and known how much cereal was in it you have to understand a lot about the world in order to interpret this case it is just as hard as understanding written english and so even if we somehow took the law and turned it into computer code it would still be hard for the for the judge the computerized judge or the computerized lawyer to see what happened in the real world and figure out what happened what you really need is a computer able to understand english and if we actually did have such computers then maybe we could eventually go to um not just self-driving cars but self-driving legal systems and that would be nice that would really be nice you could also have lawyer congress people pass laws and knowing what the law means when they pass it because a computer could check it and tell you what it would do in different circumstances uh so so laws are fuzzy because they deal with a world that is fuzzy and that's the inherent problem that said there's been a huge amount of work over decades of applying ai to law as a legal assistant what's the hardest thing a lawyer does well she has to go out and find precedent and existing cases that match the current case well how do you do that you can google it's hard to google well you could use ai to help you and in fact google itself uses ai to google so there are ways you can use ai and law but we're a long way from being able to automate the whole system but yes i think it would be great to automate the whole system okay thanks leemon okay we're going to go from hypothetical to something a lot more tangible and and real to this community um after the last coin is released mance in 15 years
chapters.title: Why are laws so difficult to interpret? Wouldn't an AI Lawyer serve as an unbiased option?

chapters.text: will hbar then become a hard currency or the will the amount of coins in circulation still be able to be adjusted right so let me just say uh two things one the intent is for it to be a hard currency it will never be changed total supply of tokens will never change uh if we have anything at all to to say about it and we have a lot to say about it so uh i'm not expecting that the total supply will ever change secondly though i think there is a mis perception still in the ecosystem at large that all the coins are going to be released out of circa out of treasury into circulating supply in 15 years that may not be the case so what i would encourage everyone to do that's interested is go look at the uh token uh what what do we call it it's we've got a token economics paper on the website that explains what our legal obligations are in terms of tokens that have to be released over a certain time period and that set of tokens is substantially smaller than total supply and so it is the case there's it's on the website it's in this document you can take a look it is the case that tokens will be released over some number of years here but when that is completed uh it's not the case that we are required to release any more tokens ever now we probably will uh will it be all the tokens in a 15-year time period probably not i could anticipate it being much longer period than that um so and there are a lot of reasons why that would be under consideration for both decentralization and you know a whole whole variety of reasons why you'd want to consider that but no one should assume at this stage that all the tokens will be in supply in 15 years all right thanks for clarifying that mance leemon what would be the ideal number of

chapters.text: shards and nodes running on the network to satisfy use cases globally and has there been any mathematics worked out towards when new shards would come online in real time oh sure so it all comes down to economics and security so for the economics you need a shard to be run by computers that are being paid enough so that you can afford to run the computer and maybe make a small profit otherwise you'll never get the computers being nodes in your chart so there have to be enough transactions coming to that shard so that the transaction fees ultimately will end up paying for these computers i mean it has to be that it has to balance out in these early days you know you can pay more than the transactions coming in but eventually it has to reach a steady state where it's self-supporting so we can have as many shards as there are transactions per second to support them and so at our really low prices still only needs a few thousand transactions per second to support a shard and then as you go to large multiples of that you can have large numbers of shards which is great you also need to have enough computers in the shard to be secure if every shard had three computers then just a single malicious computer could destroy the shard so we don't want that we want to have a large number of computers and um that comes down to assuming we're going to anonymous computers the number you need comes down to how much do you trust these people to be actually different people and how much do you trust the proof of stake to be protecting your system so you need to have lots of coins out there they need to be valuable they need to be widely distributed you need to think it isn't just one whale that has every coin in the world and then you can afford to have shards and then you want to figure out how big they are and you still trust that you're not going to have a third of the people compromised so i've always said to be somewhere between 100 and 1 000 and maybe it's in that range i don't know we have to see what we what it looks like the economics of the coins looks like and how the security derives from that but once you figure out how big the shard has to be then you can have that shard as soon as there's enough transactions per second to support it so when we have a single shard and it gets to twice that number now we can split two shards and each of them have just enough to support them and then when we grow enough uh transactions on one of them to split again then it can split again we can just keep doing that then the ultimate question is how many transactions per second will be done on ledgers on the entire planet in the distant future ultimately you know half the economy is going to flow through ledgers so the number is just astronomical and so the number of shards would be astronomical but um that's the the final end state all right thanks leemon mance will there

we are not going to go to a world with no ads we're going to go to a world where you have a choice so what do you like better hulu or netflix you want to watch for free and have ads or do you want to pay and have a subscription or even a better example what do you like better youtube or youtube you can watch youtube for free if you're willing to watch the ads or you can pay a subscription and not get the ads and so this i think is the world that we need to head to even more we need to give people a choice do you pay or are you watching ads and if you are paying then you need to be able to set it up where it protects privacy and it is possible to do that if you're watching ads there's this huge conflict of interest that makes it hard to have privacy because how do they know a real person actually saw it if you don't really know who that real person is and the advertisers want to know demographics so i think as long as things are supported by ads they're going to be spying on you and that's just kind of inherent and maybe you're willing to be spied on in exchange for free media but if you're paying then you could be you could set it up to have privacy and i think ledgers like hbar are going to allow you to pay for things with greater privacy and that i think is important and so i see a future where you have a choice to what degree do you want to be spied on to what degree do with kucoin and others should decentralized exchanges be a priority i love dexes but even centralized exchanges are fine if you have a lot of them and even central even a single centralized exchange would be fine if it wasn't also a custodian the real problem is that there's lots of coins sitting in the exchange so they're actually acting like a custodian if they um allowed everybody to have separate accounts and did the exchanges that way which they could do then you wouldn't have this problem of a single custodian holding lots of coins the solution to a single giant custodian holding all the coins in the world is to have lots of big custodians then they at least have to split up those coins and then have lots of services that don't need custodians and dexes are one and you're right i love dexes but even centralized exchanges are also great they're good too and and so if they do non-custodial work that's great if they do custodial work that's great too as long as there's more than one of them if there's a whole bunch of them we have 100 of them then it's fine that they're doing custodial work that's that's a benefit too and so you know only one of them gets hacked you're fine you just have to make sure that less than a third of them get hacked so i think that we are in the process the world is going to a world with more exchanges more decentralized exchanges even more of the centralized custodial type exchanges and just more custodial services in general and that's what we need we need an ecosystem that's huge that has all of these services in abundance from lots of different providers that can compete with each other on prices and you never have all of them getting hacked on the same day that's what we need and we're heading there okay and mance one last one for you in your recent interview with cmcc
chapters.title: Is it a problem that centralized exchanges can be hacked? Should decentralized exchanges be the priority?

chapters.text: global you mentioned that the ethereum enterprise alliance is running on the hedera consensus server can you unpack this for us sure so uh very briefly each of those major private network platforms hyperledger corta eea quorum etc most of them maybe all of them are architected in such a way where the consensus algorithm that they use is plugable you can choose your consensus algorithm we've already done this with hyperledger we have a plugin for hyperledger fabric that's in the hyperledger labs people are using it today what we've done internally is taken eea and replaced their consensus algorithm with hcs and demonstrated that it works so we are effectively making ethereum run on hcs this was an internal project it's not something that we've published i don't know that we would object to publishing whatever we you know whatever source code we created it was a prototype it was not productized uh but that's that's what i was talking about we've made ethereum run on hcs in our labs in the long term the plan is that we become a consensus service for every every private ledger possible and so you know eventually we'll support everything out there yeah all right well thank you to you both i know we are at the top of the hour and thank you to our community as always for joining in taking the time to listen and also to send in your questions i know we actually didn't get through everything that um we had in terms of the questions that were submitted for this month's town hall i've also seen some things flying through in the chat i would ask that if you do have a question we do try to answer as many as we can but please submit them through the form so that we can make sure they get in the queue for next month's chat so everybody stay safe and well out there and we look forward to seeing you all soon have a good one thanks everyone thanks a lot
chapters.title: Ethereum Enterprise Alliance running on Hedera Consensus Service

entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our seventh Town Hall. Topics ranged from Leemon's thoughts on shared worlds in VR & AR, how appnets work, as well as what it means for Hedera to be regulatory compliant.

Timestamps for this video:
0:00 Intro
0:21 What would Leemon's vision of shared worlds look like in virtual reality (VR) or augmented reality (AR)?
5:06 What does it look like when Hedera supports an ecosystem of companies whose users can float from one to another, a seamless way for users to take advantage of each company?
8:21 Is hashgraph's use of a median wall clock time, as a core part of consensus, vulnerable to skewing?
12:37 Comments on Google / EOS relationship news
16:04 Why has the upgrade to the network been delayed?
18:48 Are any Governing Council members developing multiple use cases?
19:53 What is being done to entice more developers to build using Hedera?
21:22 Governing Council member announcement plans
26:58 What are the benefits of using Base 10 in arithmetic? How are different based arithmetics applied and used in cryptography?
31:32 What does it mean for Hedera to be regulatory complaint? Would it be possible for Hedera to comply with a court ordered cryptocurrency transaction reversal?
36:31 Is there a Special Interest Group for synchronization?
37:59 Why are laws so difficult to interpret? Wouldn't an AI Lawyer serve as an unbiased option?
41:20 After the last HBAR is released, will it then become a hard currency or will the amount in circulation still be adjusted? 
43:34 What is the ideal number of shards and nodes running on the network to satisfy global use cases?
46:11 Will there be automotive companies in the Governing Council?
47:10 Will the Council ensure that node operations are conducted in a global geographically distributed manner?
48:34 Referring to The Social Dilemma documentary, how long will it take to replace the current ad-based monetization model with one that allows the user to own and monetize their own data?
51:20 Is it a problem that centralized exchanges can be hacked? Should decentralized exchanges be the priority?
52:59 Ethereum Enterprise Alliance running on Hedera Consensus Service


Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://www.hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://www.hedera.com/discord
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/hashgraph
Reddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/hashgraph
Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/whitepaper
Consensus Service Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/consensus-service

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | October 2020

chapters.text: hello hedera community this is our sixth monthly town hall um and we appreciate all of you joining and we love getting the questions in throughout the month and we love being able to share with you so um again thank you and uh without further ado i will jump in because we've got a lot of great questions that were sent to us um uh this time as a reminder and we can't really do the questions in the chat because those are going a little fast for me personally but um you know you will uh we do solicit these questions ahead of time so please continue to send those in um all right so mance let's start with you
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: and um we're going to jump in to talk about business models um did you ever consider a non-profit not-for-profit business model yes actually we sort of have a non-profit or not-for-profit business model sometimes the corporate structure implies a business model but not always for example we don't pay dividends to the members of the llc there is no terminal value in the llc if we were hypothetically to to sell it it were to uh you know cease doing business whatever proceeds or assets there would be there at the end we go to charity we operate very much like a a non-profit in in pretty much all ways the reason we're an llc versus a different structure it has everything to do with corporate liability and the liability protection is provided by the llc structure and so while i understand it can be confusing i mean a lot of people hear that hedera is a corporation uh and they immediately assume what was would normally be the case that the corporation exists to make profits that's not the case for adera we operate and in all respects are like a non-profit we just have the protections of an llc all right thanks vance um leemon we're gonna dive right in um on
chapters.title: Did Hedera consider a not-for-profit organization model?

chapters.text: uh math theory here today with you so what was the 34 math theory referred to in regards to security oh yeah so byzantine fault tolerance you know where abft where asynchronous byzantine fault tolerance but just byzantine fault tolerance in general is the network will keep running even if almost a third of the nodes are malicious they lie they do bad things and the bad guys control the internet to a large degree uh and as long as they occasionally let messages through we're guaranteed to keep making progress we'll eventually reach finality we'll all agree on the consensus we'll never have some of us having one consensus and some having another all these good things are bft and to do that you have to say more than two-thirds of the nodes are honest and and active at least occasionally active which means that you have to have less than a third of the nodes controlled by the bad guys and the bad guys can control the internet they have to control less than a third of the nodes and that's true of any bft algorithm uh it's true of hedera it's true of any of the algorithms there are some algorithms that are worse where it can only tolerate up to a fifth being bad or a tenth being bad or something but but a third being bad is the worst is the is the best kind of algorithm you could build that can tolerate up to almost a third being malicious uh and controlling the internet and you could say well why is that well turns out it's pretty simple the the proof is pretty simple that if you wanted to build an algorithm that could tolerate a full third it's impossible if a full third are malicious 33.3333 percent you know 34 percent were malicious they could either shut you down and make sure your network never comes to consensus or they could corrupt you and make you come to two different consensuses and you could have double spins and all those bad things and the reason is really simple algorithms that are bft always say we have to have more than two-thirds honest and we have to have more than two-thirds of the computers actually running in order to make progress what if we tried to reduce that and make an algorithm that is happy at exactly two-thirds it doesn't need more than two-thirds what if we wanted to do that it's impossible and here's why if this algorithm is going to be perfectly happy coming to consensus with just two-thirds then imagine that just two-thirds of the nodes are honest so this is two-thirds of the nodes these are the honest guys and down here we have one-third that's dishonest of these two thirds that are honest the bad guys control the internet they could put a firewall in that prevents the honest people from talking to each other so this is one third of the population they're honest this is one third they're honest and they can't talk to each other through this firewall but down here at the bottom we have the dishonest guys and they allow themselves to talk through the firewall they can talk to these guys and they can talk to these guys over here so now what happens the dishonest plus these good guys make up two thirds they can come to consensus and if it's a yes no question maybe they just decide it's yes but these honest guys the ones over here and the bad guys also can come to consensus and maybe the consensus is no and now we come to two different consensuses if you let the group come to an agreement with just two-thirds of us they could come to consensus and they could be different consensuses and you could do a double spend because maybe the consensus is opposite on which of two transactions happen first and so you end up with double spins it'd be terrible so we have to say two-thirds isn't enough for consensus i need just more than two-thirds that prevents the attack i just described but if it takes just more than two-thirds to reach consensus then this one-third at the bottom just by shutting down can freeze the whole network and so either way you build your algorithm that one-third can either shut down the entire network forever just by turning off their computers or they can use their malicious firewalls to make you come to false consensuses inconsistent consensuses which of course is not consensus so either way you fail and you fail in a really bad way and so we cannot tolerate a full one-third being bad controlled by a bad guy who also controls the internet in a lot of fundamental ways so that's why every bft algorithm requires just under one-third being malicious and um because you know you couldn't build an algorithm where it can handle more than one third being malicious if you care about double spins but then less than a third wheel to shut you down any other algorithm is going to have a limit of less than a third for doing bad things so that's the best you can do and that's what we do we do the one third thing all right thank you leemon i know that's a complex topic i'm sorry i should also mention in our youtube videos if you look at the one in harvard it goes through that whole argument in um with pictures so i'd recommend you go look at the harvard video that we have on our website and on youtube um so sorry go ahead no worries thank you okay mance um i will love the next one

chapters.text: over to you uh beyond starter programs like the hedera boost program how do you plan on supporting long-term innovation and rewarding projects with positive impact within the community yeah well so to date we have given i don't know the exact number but dozens of grants token grants coin grants to various projects for various reasons uh some of them are building products some are pursuing you know other activities but there are a lot there have been a lot of different grants that have already been awarded to a whole range of different projects within the community we have a committee it's called coincom it's the latest iteration of the type of work that we've been doing from the beginning coincom though is a new committee uh formalized just recently in fact we had our first official meeting of coincom this morning and it's the it's the job of coincom to basically come up with policies for these types of grants and what we want to do with the treasury and how to use the treasury to incentivize the creation of usage and utilization of the network in general and focus on models that are gonna survive in the long term you know there's a lot going on in the space of crypto today much of it is not sustainable uh and we sort of recognize that everybody recognizes that the question is how to achieve the benefits that you want while creating sustainable um ecosystem partners that are using the platform and and that's what the function of coin com is and coincom will be using treasury to that in in the coming weeks months and years all right thank you mance and leemon the next couple we have a few

chapters.text: questions on hbar and how it works so um this first one is i've heard that fees for the network are in u.s dollars so while hbar price might vary the cost of transaction is stable but i've also heard that transactions are paid for in h bars and the cost of transactions will be cut if the h4 value goes too high bringing network costs with it so i'm very confused can you explain some of these scenarios yeah so it's actually really simple i think there's been people get confused about the words what we have done is we have first decided what the prices should be in u.s dollars so 100th of a cent to do a crypto transfer whatever we've decided prices at us dollars and then we have to charge nh bars that's how the network works but we use the exchange rate from the exchanges we have we go out and find what the exchanges are saying the exchange rate is and so the price in h bars is derived from the price in dollars according to the current exchange rate and that updates once an hour so once an hour that exchange rate gets updated and every time you get a receipt from the network it actually includes the current exchange rate in it and we have a file on the network you can download that shows you the current exchange rate and what it will be next hour so you can even know what it will be in the next hour and so you can always see what the exchange rate is it's fluctuating with the market and so the price in dollars stays constant while the price in h bars goes up and down and you could have decided to do it the opposite way make the price in h bars be constant and the price in dollars would go up and down but what we find is that users really appreciate being able to budget for their business and to plan out what things are going to cost um and so we wanted to make the price in dollars be stable but we also could have gone with neither of them being stable and just let there be a market that makes both of them fluctuate we didn't do that we wanted to help out the businesses that are building on us and so and just ordinary people too if you want to be able to budget for what things are going to cost and so what we do is we set the prices in dollars and then once an hour the price in h bars changes so that the price in dollars will be the same and so yes if h bars become more expensive if you have to pay more dollars to get an h bar then the number of hbars you have to pay for a transaction is less that way the cost in dollars is the same and so the real cost to you is constant now we can always change the price in dollars too we have a committee that does that coin coming that this morning i'm chairing that committee we set the prices but we don't change the prices very often i don't think we've even changed them in the last year i think we changed the prices very infrequently the price in dollars but the price of h bars changes once an hour so i hope that's clear we're just trying to set it up in a way to be as convenient for two people as possible so you pay in h bars but it will always be as many h bars as necessary to reach the right number of dollars all right thank you leemon and then a follow-up to that one

chapters.text: when hedera council members participate in other dlt organizations is that a conflict of interest i don't think so um so i have several thoughts on this first we've never required the members to be exclusive to hedera and i doubt that any of the companies that we're working with would ever provide exclusivity to a single platform for the role that they play in the platform that being a you know a managing member uh one of many managing members in a platform it's not in their business interest necessarily to give exclusivity for that role to a single platform so second you know for it to be a conflict of interest for a member would require that that member is somehow benefiting at the expense of hedera and frankly i don't see that happening i don't see how that would happen how would a single member benefit by at the expense of hedera by participating in multiple platforms so the platforms clearly are in conflict i mean the platforms are competing in in many cases not all cases but i mean we don't compete with every platform in the market but we do compete with some and so the platforms hypothetically could be competing with each other um so i would expect and i know that some of our council members are part of the the the you know the governing equivalent of a governing body or an advisory body to some of the other platforms but i'm happy to compete with those platforms that doesn't worry me in fact it's kind of the opposite their council members may represent potential targets to join hedera hashgraph and i'm fine with that kind of a competition i'm not worried about our members somehow damaging hedera for their personal benefit all right thank you mance okay leemon um i'm not sure we would refer to them

about how that works because although it's bft it's not abft so that was a lot of word salad let me say it again particular algorithms for consensus hashgraph pbft let's take something else um like abft is a property of these things bft is a property of these things but the things themselves the algorithms themselves are proof of work or pbft or hashgraph so i hope that made sense and it's hard discover it's empty or they fail to mail it to you don't know the internet you can go to the store and ask for a refund and they will send you money or you can go to your bank and ask for a charge back and they will send you money and then they will go get that money from the store and then they will charge that store a fine and if the store does it too many times they charge them a really big fine or kick them out and don't let them use the credit card anymore that's how chargeback works chargeback is when you ask the credit card for the refund instead of the store in the world of cryptocurrency you can imagine similar things i pay somebody some cryptocurrency and i don't get what i paid for now if i'm paying for information or something digital like digital ownership of something that's been tokenized then we can use uh smart contracts so we can use hcs and we can ensure that you get what you paid for guaranteed but when we start to use it for other kinds of things like using cryptocurrency to buy something over the internet it's going to be mailed to you it is possible there will be fraud it is possible to do the wrong thing so what are your options well you can always go to the seller and say hey i didn't receive it could you please give me a refund and they could send you cryptocurrency back but what if they're a fraudster you could then talk about having third parties become third-party companies to help you out i love this idea as the field matures i think this is what we're going to see a lot of and there's two different ways they could do it could be set up lots of different legal ways lots of different technical ways so all of that has nothing to do with ledgers but it is part of the ecosystem on top of ledgers that i think we'll see grow over time i think we're going to see all kinds of the equivalent of binding arbitration and things coming into our world and we even put in sort of binding arbitration keys in our smart contracts have yet thought of the breakthrough we need to do natural language understanding so maybe someday i hope so and maybe ledgers will play a role i hope so on that too long answer to a simple question chapters.title: Leemon elaborates on AI reading limitations and the need for strong ontology.

chapters.text: you know i know many of you on this call know this um we are the day before and the anniversary of open access which was um a year ago tomorrow on september 16th and so would love to get from both of you your thoughts and and experience and any other things you'd like to share when reflecting on this past year okay well i'll i'll kick it off i guess um it's hard to believe number one that it's already been a year since open access it's flown by what impresses me is that through the course of the year we've been able to continue making progress in general i mean we've added some fantastic council members to the council biggest names in the world we have of the dapps that we are aware of and perhaps there are a lot more there that we're unaware of i mean to for a developer to use the network doesn't require them to talk to us at all right and so undoubtedly there are people using the network that we know nothing about but of those that are using the network we are we know that there are 47 real dapps real companies that are building applications that are meaningful applications across 15 different industry verticals that's amazing the breadth and depth of that in one year is is gratifying right um we also have 47 on-ramps that that we didn't have a year ago so we've made great progress in terms of uh the on-ramps the custa custodians and wallet providers and exchanges etc that sort of thing still some work to be done there but uh really good progress for the first year and we've grown to about 15 tps over the course of the year which if you consider is fantastic it's twice what ethereum is today and if you were to look at ethereum after year one i don't even i don't know what they were but it's many times hundreds and hundreds of percent improvement over what ethereum was after just their first year so we're very happy with uh with the progress that's been made today and the next year uh you know i'm really anxious to see where we are september 16th of next year uh i know a lot of good things that are going on i i'll be you know anxious to see those get closed and announced to the public and do this again a year from now oh i agree it has been a wild year we have seen so many good things we've seen the council grow we've gotten people like google and lg electronics and a whole bunch of others have joined the council in the last year we have seen the network itself get better we added the consensus service a year ago we didn't even have the consensus service uh this was just something we've added and the response to that has just been overwhelming uh everybody wanted it in fact people were even using our currency service as a fake consensus service because they were so desperate for it they were doing little tiny transactions using the memo field just to record things because they really wanted a consensus service and so it's been exciting to see people getting excited about that and over the next year um i think we're going to see some big users of the network big council members joining maybe new features in the network uh i am really looking forward to being able to talk about all the things that i see on the horizon right now for the next year uh it's just gonna be fun to see what happens and this year was a bad year from kova to fires to everything else i am looking forward to next year not having those problems and if if we were able to grow and and mature and build and reach an ecosystem in the midst of all these problems i'm looking forward to what happens next year when we don't have all these problems so this is looking forward to a good year next year all right well thank you so much leemon and mance as always for your time
chapters.title: Reflecting on Open Access and achievements made over the past year

chapters.text: um community thank you for your time and especially those where it's 2 a.m 7 p.m 5 a.m we really do appreciate you guys tuning in and i just want to reiterate if you have questions uh you know there will be a form that gets sent out a couple weeks before each of these so please make sure that you include those in there so that we can try to address as many of those as possible we had a number more this year i know we didn't get to do any of the fun stuff um this time but we will certainly try to include some of those next time and as always we really appreciate your time and your energy and your passion and your interest in hedera so thank you and everybody have a great day thank you thanks
chapters.title: Closing

entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our sixth Town Hall. Topics ranged from how we got in contact with Deepak Chopra for the Never Alone initiative, did Hedera consider a non-profit business model, as well as Mance and Leemon's thoughts on the past year since Open Access.

Timestamps for the questions in this video
0:00 Intro
0:41 Did Hedera consider a not-for-profit organization model?
2:16 What is the 34% math theory regarding distributed network security? (BFT vs ABFT)
7:31 How can Hedera support long-term innovation and reward projects within the community?
9:42 How are hbar transaction fees managed?
12:37 How do businesses get hbars needed to pay for transactions without going through exchanges? 
14:18 How did Coro Global (formerly Hash Labs) get a hashgraph license and why not build on HCS?
16:23 How did Hedera Hashgraph get connected with Deepak Chopra? 
19:00 With the Hedera Governing Council fill all 39 seats by the end of 2021?
21:58 When Hedera Council members participate in other DLT organizations, is that a conflict of interest?
24:08 Will non-council nodes be allowed after all 39 Governing Council seats have been filled?
25:30 How does Hedera keep focused while being able to react to outside market forces?
30:39 Is there a training sandbox for developers? https://www.hedera.com/get-started
31:38 Will there be certification programs available? 
35:25 What Hedera tokenization projects are there?
37:35 Practical byzantine fault tolerance (pBFT) vs asynchronous byzantine fault tolerance (ABFT)
41:35 Will DLTs offer a chargeback system similar to credit cards? 
45:48 When and how are Governing Council meeting minutes published?
46:58 Leemon elaborates on AI reading limitations and the need for strong ontology.
53:32 Reflecting on Open Access and achievements made over the past year
57:37 Closing

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://www.hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://www.hedera.com/discord
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/hashgraph
Reddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/hashgraph
Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/whitepaper
Consensus Service Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/consensus-service

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

chapters.text: more about who was allowed to participate in the recent fundraising and why sure so hedera has always taken a very careful approach to regulatory compliance this has been reflected in all of our fundraisings to date the staffs were conducted as private placements of securities and offerings that were exempt from registration under the securities act but complied with securities laws um while the saf was a security we do not believe the hbars should be treated as a security but rather as a commodity and however we do not have certainty about whether the sec or securities regulators will agree with that position because of the regulatory uncertainty in the market today and reflecting our governance by diverse enterprises with different risk profiles in this latest round of fundraising we structured the hbar sale agreements to comply with both the requirements for swaps under the commodities exchange act and the federal securities laws both so to comply with the commodities laws all purchasers must qualify as quote eligible contract participants which in the case of natural persons or people may substantially exceed the requirements for accredited investors and securities offerings there's a long definition of eligible contract participant and other requirements in the commodities laws which can be read online just go check it out i can't go through all of that here but for example just speaking generally for an individual to be an eligible contract participant he or she needs to have millions invested in aggregate on a discretionary basis and by structuring the deal as the commodity swap we satisfied both the requirements for the cftc and the sec simultaneously in other words while we continue to maintain the position that h bars be treated as commodities not as securities structuring the sale in this way ensures that the agreements met the requirements both for the securities law's exemption uh if the sec were to uh the agreements met both the cftc requirements and the securities law exemption requirements if the sec work hypothetically in the future to decide that the token is a security and so all of that is to say we it reflects chapters.text: measured gets managed so what metric is the hedera management team using to measure how well hedera is doing at achieving its why of becoming the trust layer of the internet yeah well so from the beginning when making critical decisions that affect the trajectory of the company our guiding light has always been let's maximize excuse me maximize the probability that hedera will be a network that serves the market for a hundred years you've heard us talk about wanting to be a hundred year company that in itself is not a metric but it deeply informs our decision process and so as for the metrics there are two top level categories that we measure progress against all of our kpis and okrs flow from these two decentralization and utilization so under decentralization our guiding light is to ensure that the network will continue to operate even if all the hedera staff were to leave the company that's the goal post right and there are two subcategories that we use for measuring decentralization they follow as under technical indicators and operational indicators technical indicators measure code completeness operational indicators measure the maturity of our processes and the transfer of responsibilities from the staff of hedera to the council members so that's how we're measuring decentralization for utilization we look at tps growth ecosystem integration in other words integration with exchanges wallets custodians etc the growth of community tools such as explorers and sdks and the diversity of usage across the market segments in other words the range of projects in our pipeline from startups to small and medium business to enterprise projects all of these measures collectively give us a sense of how we're doing in terms of growth and market adoption so in short i'm very happy with the progress today everything is looking good and yes we measure a lot here in the dara thanks mance all right leemon um one of my favorite topics use cases um

balance of your account and then you have the history which is all the transactions that have ever affected your account or the current state is for each of the consensus service topics uh what is the running hash right now of all the messages that have flowed through this service and what have all the messages that have gone in the last three minutes that's the current state and then the history market and we didn't really know exactly where the traction would come you know what the use cases might be that we would see over time as the industry began to understand this is something very different than what they'd seen in past if you go from a dozen transactions per second to potentially 10 000 tps then the use case is potentially going to be different than what you've seen and over the past almost a year now what we've seen is a lot of interest in really three categories of use cases one is immutable audit log for data sharing the idea here is a category simply that it's it's used by multiple organizations that are coming to agreement on a shared view of the data generally speaking number two is proof of action uh as it's almost as a service think of it like a service and in this case hcs that their consensus service service is is being hcs service is being integrated into existing workflows to record in real time the activities or actions that are being taken as part of that workflow ad stacks is a good example of this by recording in real time when end users click on links that result in advertising impressions another example might be recording when users make requests to have their pii their personally identifiable information removed from a database these kinds of activities and then finally we're seeing a lot of interest in tokenization not pay for your transactions using the currency of that ledger then if the price of the currency doubles the cryptocurrency doubles then basically the cost of using a ledger just doubled uh that's horrible what what businesses want and we've been talking to them they want predictable pricing so what we have is something that we keep hearing from customers they really like you pay for your transactions like the hcs messages you pay for your transactions in h bars you have to i mean that's just for technical reasons every currency every ledger has to be paid for with its currency but what are h bars well h bars of course are just our cryptocurrency and the price floats up and down and it could double or have or whatever you know you could do anything and if the price goes up you'd say ah then everything gets more expensive except if the price goes up what you mean is that when we trade on the exchanges people are paying more dollars for hbars we have a computer that goes out to all the exchanges and pulls them um once an hour and says what is the current price of hbars it takes all of those and then takes a median and it's a weighted median according to how much traffic is going on in those different exchanges and so we get this price of h bars this exchange rate and then our exchange rate tool gives that to the hedera network and if the price of h bars in dollars doubles it becomes twice as expensive to buy an h bar then we start charging you half as many h bars to do a transaction so that the cost to you is constant this is a powerful concept maybe eventually everybody else will start copying it because i think right now we're the only ones doing this if the price of hbars doubles then the number of hbars you have to use to do something gets cut in half and it balances out and the cost to you becomes predictable and businesses of course and individuals care about having low prices but they also care a lot about having predictable prices and so we do both we have incredibly low prices but we also have them being predictable and we have found that people are very very interested in the predictability agreed all right thanks leemon um mance here's a
