entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird, and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our fifth Town Hall. Topics ranged from Mance and Leemon's vision for the future, what the last thing the Governing Council voted on, how Hedera can be used for supply chain tracking, and more.

This month's fun questions also didn't disappoint. What's Leemon's favorite scuba diving destination? What music is Mance listening to? Does Leemon like cats or dogs?

Watch to find out!

Timestamps for questions in this video
0:00 Intro
0:23 What is Leemon's vision for the future?
4:43 How many TPS can Hedera expect to achieve in actual usage by end of 2020 and 2021?
7:13 Can you keep your old account ID after generating a new account?
9:05 Who was allowed to participate in the recent fundraising round and why?
12:09 Has the Hashgraph Consensus Algorithm White Paper been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals?
15:12 What metric is the Hedera management team using to measure how well Hedera is doing at achieving it's "why"?
17:46 How could Hedera be used for use cases such as supply chain tracking?
20:15 How can Hedera contribute to opening information flows through decentralization of the internet? 
21:26 Who is the most recent employee added to Hedera's engineering team?
23:12 How does Hedera account expiration work? 
26:46 What was the most recent Governing Council vote on?
28:02 Who enters the answers to the FAQ on Hedera's website?
28:50 Where is the proof that the sharded Hedera network is asynchronous byzantine fault tolerant (ABFT)? 
32:27 What is Hedera's primary use case?
35:26 What happens to the cost of transactions as the price of hbar rises?
38:11 Is Hedera for, against, or neutral about becoming the defacto digital trust layer of sovereign currencies? 
38:58 Are there concerns that too many nodes will run on Google Cloud or Amazon Web Services?
38:57 Is Hedera seeing increased interest in enterprise usage to provide security and speed to the range of supporting technologies required to facilitate a distributed workforce?
43:09 What happens if the dollar (USD) crashes and a new monetary system is established? Would that affect the transaction fee in any way?
43:44 What stops Council Members from starting their own distributed ledger technology (DLTs)?
45:17 Can a decentralized network avoid political incorrectness? How will governance deal with censorship on Hedera? 
47:40 Is Hedera going to move to a work-from-home model for the foreseeable future?
49:39 Where is Leemon's favorite scuba diving destination?
50:42 What projects in the general blockchain/DLT space does Mance find the most interesting?
51:11 Does Leemon prefer cats or dogs?
51:30 Does Mance listen to music while he works?
53:14 What Dungeons & Dragons character does Leemon prefer?
54:17 What is Mance's favorite pasta dish?
55:26 Awesome logo design from XTRA_HRDCOR_HBAR
56:25 Poll for Community name results!

Developer resources:
Chat: https://hedera.com/discord
Docs: https://docs.hedera.com/guides
GitHub: https://github.com/hashgraph
Testnet Access: https://portal.hedera.com

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://www.hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://www.hedera.com/discord
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/hashgraph
Reddit: https://www.reddit.com/r/hashgraph
Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/whitepaper
Consensus Service Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/consensus-service

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | August 2020

chapters.text: thank you everyone for joining us welcome to our july town hall and as you guys all know i'm here with leemon baird and mance tarman so um thank you hello community we hope everybody is staying safe and healthy and sane wherever you might be around the world and again we really appreciate everybody logging in from all over different time zones it's so nice to connect with our community when we all have to be apart for a little bit so we've had some great questions come in and this time i don't know if we're going to get to all of them because we have a lot but we will try to make sure we address some important ones and then also have some fun ones to wrap up with and give you a little more insights into um into mance and leemon um but mance we are going to start at the top with a question that we've been hearing a lot and some of the members of the community
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: have been having issues with the wallet so we'd love to just address that up front and um you know and share with them what's going on yeah so thank you all for the question it was an expected question an anticipated question uh we have been collecting feedback there is an update coming that should address the issues of the recent weeks but i i want to also say that in addition we've partnered with a developer of one of the top wallets in the industry in the crypto space and they have agreed to make the transition from a hedera wallet our hedera wallet to their wallet seamless that means that in the future relatively near future when their wallet rolls out with support for hours you will be able to use your 24 word passphrase to add your hedera account to their wallet and you will be able to keep your same account number i know that's important to a lot of people understandably and so we will continue to maintain the hedera wallet until the community has been given a chance to migrate to a third-party wallet so over time we will maintain the wallet there'll be plenty of time to migrate to uh to another wallet and we will provide a lot more details about this in the coming weeks all right thanks man limit next one is for you
chapters.title: Can you address issues with the Hedera Wallet?

chapters.text: some other ledgers are starting to talk about having millions of smart contract transactions per second will hedera do this oh yeah so sure it just depends on how you're defining your terms so a core central ledger has some limits on speeds but then you can have side chains inside ledgers and you can have shards within your ledger and you can have aptness using the consensus service and there's all these ways of having outsiders doing some of the work and of course if you do that if you spread over basically lots of different networks then you can do millions or billions or trillions or quadrillions per seconds however many networks you stand up and so uh all of those things will happen we will of course do that too just like other people do it so you know they're saying well using layer two solutions or sharding or something else we can get millions that's true now of course it's only for certain transaction patterns if every single transaction is is touching the same account and you need to have the balance updating and be aware everyone being aware of it instantly then you start slowing down no matter how you try to spread it out but as long as things are kind of spread out well then you can split them across shards or across side ledgers or across independent ledgers that have interledger communication or across app nets with hcs and you can get as high of a speed as you want so you always want to look at exactly what we're talking about when we say transactions per second it means lots of different things all right thanks leemon um the next one simon sinek says that successful
chapters.title: Will Hedera accomplish millions of transactions per second?

chapters.text: companies have clearly identified what their why is and i just want to add that the marketing team at hedera loves simon sinek and we fully subscribe to his start with the y um hedera is great at answering the how behind their sophisticated technology um leemon if you want to take this one what would you say is hedera's why yes why do we even exist it is to produce the trust layer of the internet a utility that will be here for a hundred years that allows people to any time you want to carve out a piece of cyberspace for yourself that was the original vision this is enabling it to enable you to do um decentralization decentralized trust to allow you to do and disintermediation to allow you to do privacy to allow you to do all the things that you want to be doing for the whole world at high speed with the highest standards of security but the bottom line why is that we want to be the trust layer of the internet for the planet for the next century and make it just possible for anyone to be involved you don't have to be a major bank or a major company to do something that anybody can do it anytime they want to very cheaply very fast very easily that is why we exist and that is what we are all focused on from the very beginning there were perhaps a number of projects whose goal was that next month we all get rich that has never been what we have been trying to do we've been trying to build something real that will be here for a hundred years and make the entire world better that is the goal awesome okay um we always get some questions about the council this time is no different um man have there been any prospective council members
chapters.title: What has Hedera identified as its "why"?

chapters.text: that you sought out but then later turned down because the prospect's expectations were not maybe in line with what the council does yeah this is actually a pretty short answer and the answer simply is yes there have been i mean we engage in lots and lots of conversations with potential council members all the time and the potential members get eliminated for a wide variety of reasons and so you know for every council member that we announce it's probably i'm shooting from the hip here it's probably the case that we've spoken to 20 that uh are not being announced so yeah it happens all the time all right and leemon um ad stacks just announced that they recorded a billion
chapters.title: Are there any council member prospects who did not agree to join the Governing Council?

chapters.text: events on the hashgraph mainnet and um someone noted that the mirror nodes have only recorded around 200 million transactions since open access can you clarify oh yeah so an event is when somebody sees an ad on a website you know it's an impression where you go to a website you see an ad and the advertiser will be to pay for that that impression the website will need to be paid for that impression and ad stacks in the middle is making all that happen they do all the magic to make sure all those payments flow that is an event then if you click on it that's an event these are what they mean by events and what they do is they bundle up groups of events and a group of events is a transaction so you might take 10 events and turn it into one transaction and the transaction would include a hash of that list of events so that you can prove in the future that's really what happened and then the transactions are what go into hedera that's the number you just reported um yeah 200 million is pretty cool in the last 10 months we've had 200 million transactions and those are completely independent things that flow through the network they reach consensus and they're operated on and then if you really want to get confused if you look at our actual underlying algorithm we have all these math terms one of our math terms is event where you take a bunch of transactions and put them inside of an event that is even more confusing because it has nothing to do with an adsdax event so you might take several ads accidents to put them into a transaction and then put several transactions into a hedera event and then those go through the consensus algorithm um so it's just good to keep track of it all the important thing is that we're talking about lots of throughput on hedera 200 million in the last 10 months and one customer is doing or one user is doing an amazing amount of things in the advertising industry with a billion events that they have now uh recorded so that's that's very impressive and our hats are off to and stacks for what they've achieved it's amazing thank you leemon for clarifying that um all right next one man's for you let's continue on council and can you provide some more context on
chapters.title: What is the difference between "events" and "transactions" on the mainnet?

chapters.text: swisscom's departure from the council yeah so if i remember correctly swisscom blockchain was the very first to sign the paperwork joining the hedera council even though they got announced with a group i believe they were the very first one to to actually sign on the dotted line so to speak to become a council member they are a small swisscom blockchain is a small subsidiary of swisscom and in recent months the swisscom blockchain organization has undergone structural changes that resulted in their leaving the council had nothing to do with the relationship with the council or anything it had everything to do with the structural changes taking place within their organization i think also maybe it's worth noting that in our february council meeting the council approved a set of criteria for membership that swisscom blockchain as an organization does not meet today we certainly did not ask them to leave the council but under the new guidelines they would not qualify today as a new potential council member i should say that kamal yusefi and the whole swisscom blockchain team contributed significantly to hedera and in its you know first phase of creating and growing the council we're grateful for the role that they played in that earliest phase of the council i have a great deal of respect for kamal in particular and uh for the rest of the team there swisscom blockchain and i you know just say that for any other further questions i would point you to kamal's blog on matter i think it speaks for itself thanks mance and yep that blog is available on the hedera site okay leemon um going back to the code if the code becomes open review will there be a bug
chapters.title: Can you share more context around the departure of Swisscom Blockchain from the Governing Council?

where you get credit for your hard work in addition to a prize that's what we'll be doing that's great to hear early man thank you all right man i'm going to love the next one over to you um what regulators besides the sec who i
chapters.title: Will there be a bug bounty after Open Review?

chapters.text: know we've talked about previously has hedera had regular contact with yeah so we have both direct and indirect contact with a wide range of regulators and policy makers lawmakers at both the federal and state level we speak directly to the regulators at the federal level of course we've talked about the sec we've mentioned cftc and treasury and we speak indirectly to these and more through our participation in organizations like the digital chamber of commerce run by perry anne boring and the at the federal level and the texas blockchain council run by lee bratcher at the state level and through these meetings and associations we have the opportunity to provide feedback and input to frameworks that are being proposed at both federal and state level and we've seen our input and contributions reflected in the policy proposals that are coming out of the regulatory agencies and we also see our contributions shaping the proposed legislation from the lawmakers so um we have an impact and and of course that's the goal so uh sec of course is is the most and and the others i've mentioned are are less than the sec all right next one we have another council question but i think i'll love this one over to leemon um why 39 council members
chapters.title: What regulators has Hedera Hashgraph been in contact with?

chapters.text: is there math and also symbolic reasons for picking 39 oh yeah both and a degree of being arbitrary so if you have great control of the internet you can do bad attacks on any ledger if they have a third of the members collaborating to do something evil now of course we mitigate that by having big companies that care about their reputations they're not going to do something evil if they're going to get caught and they will get caught because the way transparency works but even so we wanted to make it really hard a very high bar like more than 12 of you more than a dozen companies have to um collaborate in order to do anything evil which would imply well you need more than 36 members if you want more than 12. and so uh what we said then is okay we'll just pick our nice round number around 40 people will be our our our council and then we realize well you know it's kind of convenient when a council gets together in votes if you don't have ties so an odd number would really be nice so maybe in this this round 40 we won't do that we'll do like 39 or we'll do 41 something like that so we we thought it might be nice to be odd you don't have to you can always have tie breaking rules but it's just simpler to have an odd number and then we said okay so 39 41 which one should it be and you know we're sensitive to various cultures where the digit four is is not a good thing three is better and so he said fine we won't we won't have a 4 in the number we'll make it 39 rather than 41. so it is it's a combination of all those things there's some math there's some arbitrary just ballparking there's some slight conveniences of logistics of being odd and then there's cultural consensitivity let's go for 39 and so that's what we ended up doing 39 that's where we'll end up in in in the end all right thanks for that explanation leemon mance why did the token distribution
chapters.title: Why did Hedera decide on a Governing Council of 39 members?

chapters.text: schedule change so only 34 of tokens will be released by the end of 2025. yeah so um if you only look at the schedule by itself then that's what's implied but if you read the entire report then everything i'm going to share with you here is included in that report i would encourage you to go take a look um but the chart is only what's contractually obligated as of the day of publishing that chart publicly and as of today it's not necessarily the case that there will be no more than 34 by the end of 2025 what we've moved from is sort of a 15-year inflexible schedule to a schedule that provides flexibility and enables us to make grants that will promote the use of the network in other words if we see opportunities to use the token treasury to drive usage and adoption of the network then we have the flexibility to to use the treasury in that way if we do that then we'll update the token release schedule appropriately with plenty of time for people to to react to you know and and understand what the new picture is but uh yeah that so that's that's what the uh purpose of that schedule is is you know to represent the contractual obligations at a moment in time all right understood thanks for clarifying mints okay leemon on to a question related to
chapters.title: Why did the token distribution schedule change?

chapters.text: the original hashgraph paper and the liveness quality of the abft implementation um so i'm gonna try to keep up here if transactions are sent to a single malicious node and that node then gossips out contradictory transactions could that lead to gridlock in the consensus process if other nodes refuse to accept contradictory transactions if not why not and how does gossip about gossip prevent this oh great question no that's not how it works i'll explain how it works um but good i'm really happy people are thinking about these things and you know asking questions about how could you attack it is 90 of what you do when you're building something you spend ten percent on how do i build it and ten percent on oh what a tax could there be so i love the way you're thinking but that's not actually how it works so let me tell you how it works the way it works is that if you were to create two um transactions that shouldn't both happen they're mutually exclusive i think that's what contradictory means here for example a double spend i only have one h bar in my account and i try to make a transaction that will send one h bar to alice but i also make one that will send one hbar to bob and maybe i go spend it in their stores i'm trying to get something from alice by spending an h bar in her store i'm trying to get something from bob i sit in an h bar in his store and if i get away with it i'll have bought two things worth an h bar but only spent one h bar double spins would be great for me and disastrous to the whole universe so that's not what happens what happens is i create these two transactions one of them says give a given h bar to alice one says give an h bar to bob i submit them to the network to the same node or to different nodes it doesn't matter maybe it's an honest node maybe it's a malicious node it doesn't matter either way they all they both go out to the whole network the whole network gets consensus they talk back and forth they do gossip about gossip they do virtual voting and they end up on a consensus on an ordering of all our transactions so both of these are in the order both of these two mutually exclusive transactions are in the consensus order they've all agreed maybe they all agree that alice came before bob but whatever they agreed on they all agreed on it they all agreed that bob was first or alice was first whichever way so suppose alice came before bob then once everybody has consensus then every computer all by itself without talking to anyone walks through all those transactions and makes them have the appropriate effect on the state so when they get to alice's they say i see leemon wants to give one h bar to alice fine we'll make leemon's balance go down by one we'll make alice's balance go up by one the total number of h bars in the universe is conserved it's constant and leemon just gave a coin to alice great then everybody because we're all in the same order will eventually get to bob's everybody gets to bob's later than alice's because we all agreed and then bob's transaction they say oh libya's trying to send an hbar to bob but leemon doesn't have any hbars in his account that account has zero h bars this doesn't happen and so then they all agree to do no change at all on the stake nobody will change their local state bob does not get any more h bars and for that matter i don't lose any because you can't have negative hbars so everybody changes the state the same way and the state is good no gridlock no double spins it's all good you could say what about a malicious node what if he just gave bob the coin anyway he gave a coin to alice and coin to bob or maybe a million coins to bob what if he makes a bad state ah he can't get away with that either because about once a second every single node digitally signs the state the whole state all these balances of alice and bob and everything are in a gigantic merkle tree and every second everybody digitally signs the hash at the root of the merkle tree it guarantees that every single bit in that tree is correct so everybody is signing exactly the same hash saying among other things this is alice's balance this is bob's balance and all of the honest nodes will agree they will all be digitally signing the exact same state saying that yes alice got one more coin but bob did not if a malicious node says i don't care i'm going to give a coin to bob anyway then that one node will have a different state the hash of that state at the root of the merkle tree will be different he can digitally sign it and he can send it out to everybody else and everybody else will look at it and say that signature's not good that is not a valid signature on the state i know about i'm going to ignore it and so all the honest nodes completely ignore that signature and so if more than two-thirds of the nodes are honest and a mirror node collects signatures from more than two-thirds of the nodes then the mirror node knows for sure this is true and so malicious node cannot lie about the state so there's no gridlock there's no breaking consensus and there's no double spins and you can know for sure that you're getting entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | July 2020

chapters.text: thank you for joining us for our third monthly townhall um before we get started and jump into the questions with leemonn and mance you know i just wanted to share we always try to address as many questions as we can we get a ton of these each time and we go through a few criteria in order to try to answer them and make sure that these town halls are as useful for the broader community as possible so some of those criteria include you know how often are we
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: getting the same kind of question is it appearance it's a pretty broad you know a concern or question or area of curiosity among the community the second is you know do we have meaningful information to give so we don't really engage in speculation or what if or you know things that we don't have you know some some real good solid answers for you we always want to give some some good meaningful answers and and you know the third is we also try to not overlap with questions that can be found in either the hedera faq or the hedera website so we do get a number of questions and if you browse through the website in terms of talking about things like governance or things like how is very different from a blockchain and you know some of those questions this community has been with us a long time we know we have some new users and we're excited to welcome them but we also want to be mindful of the folks who have been with us a while and you know and are already aware of the answers to those and so please definitely keep the questions coming for those of you who are new welcome we have a ton of video content and lima and mance and the rest of team have put up some really educational videos on our youtube channel so i would also encourage you to go there if some of those questions are not being answered here but please do keep the questions coming we plan to continue to have these and host them and we love hearing from the community so with that i will kick it off with one that we continue to get and i know people always love sort of the behind-the-scenes views and liman what are some of had eras engineers working
chapters.title: Criteria for questions

chapters.text: on at the moment yes so they're working on lots of different things at once of course they're working on things in the platform so we'll have things like state proofs they're working on we also have things that are demos and apps that we're showing how to use like i'm on the hcs you know different ways libraries and things and demos on the hds itself and what's interesting is interconnectivity between platforms so we working on our plugins that we have for hyper ledger and for our 3/4 and for quorum so that you can use these private ledger's and just flip a switch and turn them into an app net with hedera so you get the trust of hedera but then we're also working on ways of doing the communication between networks and so between hedera and other ledger's and so this is all interesting stuff we have our engineers working on lots of different things at once and we will be announcing various things as they get done and it's exciting to watch it all moving along great thanks leemonn and the next one mance is for you what are the steps being taken by hedera to
chapters.title: What are Hedera's Engineers working on right now?

chapters.text: mitigate and eliminate such hurdles for adoption so as to make hcs a de facto enterprise choice over private conventional ordering mechanisms right so let me just say that i am interpreting that to mean over conventional or older old-school calm old-school ordering mechanisms like raft consensus mechanisms raft and pbft and others so to answer that question we need to first really identify the most significant hurdles to adoption for dlt projects today and of course we've done that and what we found is that there are a lot of there's a lot of effort on the part of those projects to create the consortium that that they need for distributed trust the first year or two for many of these projects is spent not only in developing software but pulling together a group of participants in order to create the distributed trust this requires that the members of the consortium create business frameworks legal frameworks operational processes that govern the distributed network and that activity detracts from the more important work of creating the application and deploying the use case there is a lot of time wasted on the creating and managing of the distributed trust so that's the problem we decided to solve that's the biggest problem to realizing value in these organizations so that's what we decided to solve hcs eliminates this source of friction or hurdle to adoption if you will by literally offering distributed trust as a service and i've said it from the beginning the tech is important but the council is equally important the hedera network operated and governed by our world-class council is the product and so that's the biggest hurdle and that's what we've uniquely identified and created to solve that problem in the marketplace now there are other you know other things that we're doing that add value and make it easier to use hcs as a service and to address certain categories of use cases and all those are going to be important we'll be rolling those out in the coming weeks and months but the biggest hurdle to adoption is the one that we've already solved and and that's what we're doing with hds thanks vance um all right speaking of the council liman can you
chapters.title: What are the steps taken to mitigate and eliminate hurdles for adoption?

chapters.text: address the roles and responsibilities of the technical steering committee yeah so what we have is the council and then they're in charge and then under them are some committees that they have established so the council is the 15 companies we've we've announced so far plus more coming they'll be 39 million when we zane which we're very excited about with middle-eastern presence now you're trying to be as diversified as possible they are in control they do everything then there's of course the board of directors that they appoints or that they elect people to and there's these committees that they appoint and they can delegate various ways but they're in control now of the committees one of the most important or one very important committee you can't noah can rank them but one very important committee is the technical steering and product committee and this is the committee that is responsible for determining the roadmap of how the product will change over time what features will be added on what schedule they'll be added it talks about policies for how we run our notes how powerful doesn't no need to be and how secure it is a knowed me to me and what are the best practices to make sure that our nodes are secure we talked about those things we talked about how does the council actually digitally sign transactions to make things happen and so the committee works on those sorts of things everything that is involved in the technology and the roadmap and what the product is that's what the technical steering and product committee does and it has chapters.title: Closing and Thanks

entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, and answer questions directly from the community in our third Town Hall. Topics range from the Zain Group and future Council recruitment, addressing rumored Hedera layoffs, plans for future events and more.

This month's fun questions also didn't disappoint. What science topics does Leemon think are important? Is Leemon scared of AI and Skynet taking over? What show has Mance most recently watched?

Watch to find out!

Timestamps for Questions in This Video
0:00 Intro
0:26 Criteria for questions
2:19 What are Hedera's Engineers working on right now?
3:30 What are the steps taken to mitigate and eliminate hurdles for adoption?
6:14 What are the roles and responsibilities of the Technical Steering & Product Committee?
8:25 How are treasury funds used to incentivize development and what progress has been made within the Network Utilization & Growth Committees?
11:03 What measures are in place to scale TPS quickly?
13:53 Will Hedera be selling HBAR for tax purposes on the open market with future Council Member announcements?
16:58 When will the remaining Council Member seats be filled?
17:48 Are Council Members required to pay a fee to join the Council?
18:24 Are government organizations like the FDA or NASA eligible for Council membership?
20:50 What are the issues that could prevent appnets from choosing HCS over a mechanism like RAFT for example?
22:27 Does Swirlds have any plans to launch a DAPP?
23:20 At what point will Council Members take ownership of their equal portion of HBARs and will there be a multi-sig feature to ensure that outgoing Council members will pass on their HBARs to incoming members?
25:51 Will there ever be a time that requires Hedera to burn coins?
26:30 Why didn't the UPbit Exchange announce that LG had joined the Hedera Governing Council?
28:20 Are there any plans to host a global Hedera community event or convention?
30:45 Are there plans to increase community outreach programs such as the Ambassador Program?
31:43 How accurate are the rumors about layoffs at Hedera?
32:22 What is the biggest hurdle Hedera will need to overcome in order to be a 100-year company?
35:19 How did Zain become a Governing Council Member?
36:20 What unsolved scientific problem does Leemon think is the most exciting?
39:20 Does Leemon believe that AI will take over the world and how does DLT play a role in this?
42:15 Does Leemon have thoughts on how AI can be programmed to remove bias?
44:39 How many meals does Leemon eat a day?
46:02 What activities are you most looking forward to enjoying once quarantine is over?
48:13 What was the last TV show that Mance has binge-watched?
48:55 Closing and Thanks

Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/whitepaper

chapters.text: hello everyone i'm zenobia godschalk head of corporate communications for hedera hash grass thank you for joining us on our second quarantine townhall and it works out nicely for us since we are a distributed organization anyway as is this community so we are glad to be connected with you guys again so joining me you guys know and love them as usual our mance harmon and leemon baird and we are also going to start off today with a special guest so one of the things that we have heard from the community is that we'd love to hear more from your councilmembers we'd love to hear what they're doing we'd love to hear how they're engaged and and you know we just like to see their smiling faces so we need today to have kamal yousefi with us from swisscom swisscom was one of the first council members to join us and with our initial set of announcements and so hello kamal welcome and thank you for joining us today yes so i'm you know we have a few questions from the community i'm gonna lob them over to you and we'd love to hear from you and tell us you know now a little over a year in what has it been like

including the anonymous notes so this is the path to decentralization as a whole webinar on that the whole idea here is that we need to be secured every step along the way so initially when it's the council it's pretty easy to make it secure and it's it's proof of stake and it's just you know we're staking there the important thing though is that by the time you get to anonymous nodes if you want security against sibyl attacks where one person pretends to be a bunch of people you need to do proof of stake now you could say we'll we want everyone who's holding coins to be running a node but that won't happen some people don't want to run nodes so the only way you could really have security there is if you then have proxy staking so that most of the coins are being proxy stick to the nodes that are running that means that those nodes get credit for those coins so the way the consensus algorithm works is that the nodes are virtually voting on things on the order of the transactions and the timestamps and everything and the nodes have a weight in the vote that is weighted by how many h bars they have and that could be the node itself staking the h bars or can be other people around the world proxy sticking to that node so if you want to be secure in the final state where we have anonymous nodes you have to have proxy staking it has to have certain properties which are entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird and Mance Harmon, answer questions directly from the community in our second Town Hall. Topics range from the governing council, proof of stake, Sybil attacks, HBAR, proxy staking, Hedera Consensus Service (HCS), Hyperledger, AdsDax, public vs private vs intergalactic networks, virtual voting, and open source software.

We also include some fun questions. Where did the name ‘Hedera’ come from? What does Leemon say are the top three scientific achievements or discoveries of all time? What does Mance describe as “palate shocking”? How would Leemon colonize Mars?

Watch to find out!

Timestamps for Questions in This Video
0:00 Intro
1:23 What has it been like for Swisscom Blockchain to be part of the Hedera Council?
6:10 Which Committees is Kamal on and can he share some details about their work?
8:50 How is Hedera's proxy staking different and when will it be available?
15:54 How does HCS integrate with R3 Corda, Hyperledger and Quorum?
19:17 Are there concerns about the privacy of HBAR users?
23:32 Will there be another community testing earn program?
25:17 Does the hashgraph protocol require every participant knowing and agreeing on the total number of participants in the system?
28:34 What are the main challenges of governing council recruitment and how can people pitch Hedera Governing Council membership to their own organizations?
32:06 How easy is it to increase the 10,000 TPS throttle?
34:51 Was there any US or other government that had involvement in the development of hashgraph or Hedera?

chapters.text: been very concerned about being as compliant as is possible what we found is that there is strong demand for the h-bar we're in the process now of closing that first 10 million and a significant portion of the additional 5 has already been allocated and i'm expecting to close the the additional 5 so that's just to comment very briefly on our cash position second there really two primary metrics that we use when measuring the success of the project decentralization and usage and from the beginning we have focused on a decentralized governance model for making decisions that impact the network from for governing the network the council is now fully functional the interim board was dissolved in at the end of last year at the end of december and the first fully elected board took control in january the council manages treasury the they determine the product roadmap and they provide oversight of every part of the organization the council is operational the council is distributed and it's distributed across geographies it's distributed across industries so there is no single point of failure today in the network from a governance perspective from an operational perspective and importantly the hedera staff continues to relinquish more and more control of operations to the council and that process will continue so decentralization is going very well what about usage many of you have heard me say before the performance improvements in hash graph are like the difference between a calculator and a computer the applications that one builds for a computer are going to be very different than those applications that get built for a calculator and much of the dlt industry is now seen in hedera a computer for the very first time so the strategy is pretty simple we've identified four broad categories of uses of the hedera consensus service specifically but the platform more generally these aren't for use cases but rather for focus areas that will have interest from different types of stakeholders some will appeal to architects for example we just announced this week that we have the plugin the hyper lender fabric that is now in the labs hyper ledger and is out there for people to download and use and contribute to we can think of hcs in this context as layer 0 the consensus layer for distributed ledger implementations and we're building the set of tools and micro services that will appeal to developers making it easier for them to build solutions that business users will care about for each of these focus areas we're developing demos documentation and also working with customers to build initial reference implementations so in other words in this year 2020 we're demonstrating how a computer is different than a calculator and in 2021 our channel partners will use these reference accounts and reference implementations to scale the usage of the platform so yes we are moving towards significant usage now oh that sounds very abstract and i realize this is turning into a long answer up i'll try to be brief all of that sounding very abstract but let me try to make it concrete with an example yesterday and today you're seeing press that's talking about the coupon bureau that coupon bureau is a nonprofit service organization for the coupon industry the advisory committee for the coupon bureau includes target and general mills and gs1 it's an important standards body for the industry and they're working with leading consumer packaged goods manufacturers that provide and accelerators that provide access to point-of-sale systems at leading retailers that represent nearly 70% of the us retail market there are about 250 billion coupons registered every year in the united states and the systems that they use are ancient they're antiquated they're very inefficient in their rife with fraud the coupon bureau is working with us using hcs to modernize that and they are making it possible using hts for those manufacturers to register their coupons with the coupon bureau they transactions the coupons being used at the point-of-sale systems will flow through hts through ad era and then back to the coupon bureau in their database of coupons gets updated appropriately the manufacturers will run mirror notes so they have transparency into what it is that they are the coupons that are being used it it reduces fraud it provides an opportunity for analytics that didn't previously exist it makes the settlement process extremely efficient compared to the weeks or months that it takes today and it's going to result in a lot of tps it's a use case that you could not implement on ethereum right not not in the same way that we're talking about implementing it on hds it's these types of use cases that are really high throughput that require tiny cost i mean you couldn't have a cost of a quarter for a register or log of coupon that gives you a 50 cent discount right this economics don't work so to finish up decentralization we've made great strides in usage we are well on our way we expect to see tps scale and so yes i absolutely expect to see high tps and the coupon bureau is just one example of a slew of examples that we have in the pipeline that it will be announcing more and more of as we get through this year okay that was long-winded but hopefully that was helpful i love that very important you have to have those and i would encourage if you have large amounts think about using a hardware wallet that's a really good thing to use and if it's small amounts you need to use it frequently then use a software wallet well we have those we have a software wallet that we wrote ourself but the plan from the beginning has been to use the ecosystem and let other people do and we're as much as we can trying to emphasize these other third party wallets now that are integrated with this so that we don't have to do the wallet we'd rather have have the community donate and so we're really excited about that we also have exchanges now dozens of exchanges and otc desks so that people can buy h bars or trade h bars or convert them back and forth with other things some exchanges will create an account for you some exchanges will let you use a credit card some exchanges only do pairs but if you already have something else you can trade it for each bars and vice versa and i love that we have dozens of them now and it's on our website if you go to hedera comm / h bars it lists all a whole bunch of exchanges we don't know if any of these are good or bad i mean we're not endorsing them and i'm not even sure it's a complete list but whenever we heard about an exchange we put it on the list and we get a link to their website and you can go see if they're good or bad but i love that i mean if there were only three we actually would have investigated them but there's 27 of them now and it keeps growing and so i love that were that we're exchange growing that way there are custody services now third-party custody maybe you have a lot of money in h bars and you don't really want to trust taking care of the key yourself you'd rather have someone else who is trustworthy protect the key and make sure you don't lose it and make sure it isn't stolen so now there's custody services and h bars have been integrated into custody services that's just an important part of the ecosystem and so i love that that is there now i think there are a lot of use cases where somebody we're going to use that there are other cases where you wouldn't want to you know you either pre or post co ba'd your choice co it hasn't actually changes it very much i just walk at home instead of at the office so i every day i am working on making new algorithms for little pieces of the hedera system and that comes up all the time in architecting little things and architecting our new features and those sorts of things i love that that is so much fun and that is not the majority of my time majority of my time ends up being endless meetings on phone calls and what i do is i walk i walk on doing math math is fun and i enjoy walking while i do that but i also walk on on the phone and i will walk five or ten miles a day in little tiny circles in my living room it's terrible and i used to walk little tiny circles in my office or i'd walk through the office walk through all the hallways but now i walk in little tiny circles in my living room which is good exercise but that's my typical day but then i also had time to take take breaks and do fun things like math and even some programming i like coding but not enough of those things are you yeah well so we share that in terms of the pacing so i'm on the phone all the time similar to leemon and pacing endlessly it's different now because i'm at home so i'm either walking outside or around the house as opposed to pacing around the office what's my typical day like the the days and the nights are all about the same you know it's you're on 24/7 and so there's always work to be done you're always on the phone they're always on the computer while leemonn focuses of course on the tech i am working with on the business side and you know all the other stuff that is important for operations and and legal and counsel and board meetings and all of that so it's it's very far removed from where we started years ago you know building algorithms for machine learning and reinforcement learning and so but the the days i look you know the same it's certainly more so now in the middle of the pandemic than before the days just sort of blend together and it's an endless series of conversations while walking around the house kind of a boring existence to be honest you know motorcycles and so we could yeah well i want to thank both of you for your time
chapters.title: What does a typical day look like for Mance and Leemon?

chapters.text: i want to thank the community for those of you who submitted questions beforehand thank you so much for those of you who submitted them now we will definitely capture them and we will also likely send out the you know the forum again so that we can continue to get these questions from the community i think especially now when we're not able to travel and see people in person and you know see everyone's smiling faces and engage in you know one-on-one dialogue this is really important and we appreciate everybody taking the time we hope that this has been useful and we look forward to chatting with you all again very soon thank you very much bye you
chapters.title: Closing and Thanks

entries.description:
Hedera co-founders, Mance Harmon and Dr. Leemon Baird answer questions directly from the community in our first Community Town Hall. Topics range from the current COVID-19 climate, CBDC, Testnet communications, future network usage, comparing Stardate as Star Trek's measure of time and corporate goals but also include some fun personal questions. What video games are Leemon playing? What is Mance's favorite hobby? Watch to find out!

Timestamps for Questions in This Video
0:00 Intro
1:17 Can Leemon share an update on the Hedera roadmap?
4:14 What's the criteria for mainnet exiting beta status?
5:43 What are Hedera's plans for managing a global depression and can Hedera actually achieve thousands of TPS to drive revenue?
12:40 What is Leemon's impression of the ecosystem building around Hedera?
18:00 How happy is Mance with Hedera's progress, are there any areas that exceeded your expectations or any areas that require more progress, for example, business goals?
23:09 Can Hedera improve communication around testnet changes?
25:38 How does Mance balance the long term goals of establishing the trust layer of the internet with short term goals of targeting large enterprises?
28:26 How does Leemon expect usage to change or grow in the future?
31:11 Why has HBAR been slow to be listed on certain cryptocurrency exchanges?
33:24 Can Leemon elaborate on how time works with consensus timestamps?
39:03 Are there better fiat onramps to buy HBAR in bulk?
40:40 What's the timeline to have support on the RSA and EC keys on the Hedera network?
43:15 How does Mance think Central Banks will respond to digital currencies in terms of COVID and how likely will a global currency be safe and desirable?
45:10 Are there any repercussions if the Chinese pursue a CBDC using JointGraph?
46:34 Will state size increase over time with more users and nodes on the network?
48:12 What can a non-technical community member do to help Hedera?
49:18 What versions of EVM with Hedera use and will it always go in the same direction as Ethereum?
52:17 What is Leemon's favorite computer game?
54:23 What is Mance's favorite hobby?
55:48 What does a typical day look like for Mance and Leemon?
59:00 Closing and Thanks

Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/whitepaper
Consensus Service Whitepaper: https://www.hedera.com/consensus-service

#HederaHashgraph #LeemonBaird #ManceHarmon

entries.title: Hedera Community Town Hall | April 2020

chapters.text: uh my name is zenobia godschalk i'm the svp of communications here at hedera and i am joined by our two co-founders mance harmon and leemon baird um we are celebrating we are in the midst of earth week this week so for those who haven't seen it i would encourage you to visit our youtube channel there are a number of dapps that we have spoken with this week and we'll continue to talk to you throughout the week that are sharing just how just how green the hedera network is and how they're able to use it not only to make their dapps more energy efficient but to also build applications that are really contributing to the future of our world and contributing to make it a better place there is a report out from power transition that talks about in some very tangible numbers the differences in energy consumption of hedera versus other networks i would also encourage folks to look at those and each of the videos should have links to the applications and what they're doing so welcome to this earth week edition of our town hall and we can go ahead and get started um leemon we are going to jump in and you know we we try to tackle as many things as we can on these town halls so this month there were a number of questions from the
chapters.title: Intro

chapters.text: community on the transfer of tokens from the founders accounts and whether that involves selling and whether that occurs when the price of hbar is down oh good question no no selling when the price is substantially down so the selling happens according to a plan the plan is detailed it's published on our website if there's an faq i think maybe we'll have a link to it put into the chat but the plan says no selling when it's down and there's lots of details lots of constraints don't sell too much if the volume is slow all that stuff so that is in an faq frequently asked questions that's published on our website and of course you talked about transfers what you see are transfers from accounts but when you sell coins what you usually do is you transfer a bunch to an exchange or a third party and then throughout the day you can be selling from that and you can sell it for several days and then when the balance gets low a few days later then you transfer another tranche so the transfers and the sales aren't quite the same thing if sales stop for a day or two you might not see it just looking at the transfers if the sales stopped for weeks you would see it but not if it's just briefly but the the transfers of the sales are slightly different because of the way you normally sell and all of that is regulated by the plan was established last october and it's in the faq so um go ahead and look at that if you're curious about all the details all the numbers great thank you leemon and the um i will just note that uh the faq has been posted in the chat so feel free to take a look at that afterwards for those who want more in-depth details all right mance um in the spirit of transparency

about token price we get a lot of questions about the hbar and about token price and predictions and blah blah blah right and we don't talk about token price also there are questions that come in that chapters.text: is for you um there is a public critique of hedera that the hedera hashgraph system only provides fairness of ordering for consensus messages not for transactions within a message it goes on to say any batch node transactions can choose which one of those messages came first and which one came last sorry any node batching those transactions and they can use this small power they have for instance to front run orders for example in a stock exchange can you share with us is there any truth to the statement is it moot because all transactions are batched into one event that's gossiped out um how would this play out for example in fair ordering of bids and asks in a stock exchange oh great question so there's several different misconceptions here and this is it's not how it works so first of all when one of when you want to submit a transaction you give it to a node and that node will then send it on to the whole network it gets gossiped out if you give it to the node atlas then alice will send it to the network and if several people give alice transactions she will send them out to the network and they will end up in consensus order in the order that alice sent them out now if you send transactions to bob his will be sent out in some order and they will end up in consensus order in the order he sent them out it has nothing to do with whether they're all in one event or they're all broken up into individual events that has nothing to do with it it will always be in the order he sends them out so talking about bundling into messages or bundling into events is completely irrelevant it has no effect on this it's simply that if you send your transactions to alice the order in which she sends them out hers the one sent out by her will all be in the order she sends them out the same is true for bob the consensus is then well how do alice's and bob's interleave do they interleave like this or is it like this or is it like this or is it you know sort of like this there's lots of different ways that they could interleave that's what the what the community is to figuring out but if you just look at one node they'll end up in consensus order in the order in which that node sent them out so uh has nothing to do with messages or bundling or movement or events or whatever i've seen this misconception it's just that's not how it works so then the second question is well is it going to be fair is the community going to um end up putting them in in this order in a fair way well alice put them in an order in a fair way and of course there's three different kinds of fairness here and there's talk about front running which is maybe a fourth kind of fairness and then you know life's not fair that's a fifth kind of fairness so let's talk about the different fairnesses what we would like ideally is to put them in order in the order in which the network received them you know the new york stock exchange puts things in order in the order that they come to it's one single computer we want our ledger to act like that but since we're multiple computers what would you mean by the time at which it reached the network do you mean the time at which it reached the very first node that wouldn't make any sense maybe that node never forwarded it on and then a year from now that node tells you hey i had one i forgot to tell you about would you give it credit for having happened a year earlier well you can't do that you've already made decisions you can't undo them so it wouldn't make sense to say you have reached the network when you reach the first node okay how about it when it reaches the last node when it's reached the entire network would that be the fair time to say that's when it reached the network well not really because what if that node's turned off then the whole network would have to freeze if it's turned off for a year the whole network would freeze for a year before we ever knew what order things are in you can't really do that what if you're going to treat the network as virtually being like the single computer the new york stock exchange then the most rational thing the most fair thing is to say you have reached the network when you've reached the majority of the nodes when you reach just over half of the nodes or half the nodes you have now reached the network and because of the gossip protocol it's very hard for an attacker to stop once you're in the network at all and spreading the gossip you're going to spread out to everybody very fast and so it would be very hard for an attacker at that point to stop you from reaching half the network once you've reached a few of the nodes so fairness of time stamps come from that and so if you care about fairness of timestamps this is clearly what you would mean by fairness of timestamps but there's other kinds of fairness what about the fairness of the ordering well it seemed like the most fair way to put things in order is to do it by the time stamp why would we put them into an order different from the order at which we received them you know the new york stock exchange has a single computer it puts transactions asks and bids into order by the order it received them it would be unfair to do a different order then there's just is life fair it turns out people who live right next to the new yorker stock exchange can get their bids and ask in milliseconds faster than someone who lives far away people have spent like a hundred million dollars drilling a hole through a mountain just to get to the new york stock exchange a few milliseconds faster so you could say well it's unfair that i live far away so mine gets in later yeah okay that's life is unfair um that kind of unfairness isn't the new york stock exchange's fault it isn't their algorithm's fault it's just the fact that the world is distributed and in that sense of course we have the same problem if somebody shuts down your connection to the internet you just won't be able to bid that day and that's unfair life is unfair but if you haven't access to the internet at all we do have a fairness of access that in many ways is better than what you would get with a new york stock exchange and here's why everybody might live near a different node but as long as you give your message to your node it'll then spread exponentially fast through the network and so in that sense people around the world all get to live right next door to us whereas in new york stock exchange you have to live in new york to live right next door to the server so fairness of access is better furthermore you can choose which node you're submitting to so if you know a node is nice and honest and always gets theirs out quickly then you can choose that one so if alice always sends hers out when you send it to her you see it goes out right away you can always send it to alice and if bob tends to be kind of slow and sometimes doesn't send it at all you can just ignore bob and so you get to choose so you have fairness of access in that way and then in addition you have fairness of access in the sense that if you really wanted to get out fast you can set it to lots of those and then it truly will reach the majority of the network a little bit faster just a you know a second faster or a fraction of a second i don't know but it will get there faster and so that is a way that you can manually ensure that it gets out faster and you pay a little bit more if you send it to end nodes you're not paying in times as much you only pay once for the service but the the node fee uh you pay and the transaction fee or the network fee you pay a little bit more so you will pay in times as much on that part of the fee because you're making us do more work but that would ensure that it gets out so for fairness of access it's kind of the best that a ledger could ever have you have access to it and it's definitely better than a single server like the new york stock exchange where access is only good for people right next to it and then there's the question of um well that was it right fairness of time fairness of ordering fairness of access and then just you know kind of is life fair and then there was the question about front running if you want to be able to avoid front running even with the new york stock exchange if a server is if a router along the route is seeing your your message it might put in another message reacting to that if you want to stop front running in a public ledger where the whole world can see what's happening on every node and every node is untrusted individually then what you have to do is set up some kind of system with rounds this is the way that the world has to work and so what you would do is you use hcs the consensus service to create an app net for your auction or for your stock market and you would say okay every five seconds we'll start a new round so for the first five seconds everybody can put in their bid or ask but you only put in a hash of it so nobody can read it so nobody can read it and then front run you and at the end of those five seconds it's now too late for anybody else to put in any more hashes and we know when the five seconds ends because there's a timestamp a consensus timestamp that was fair on every transaction so we know when the time limit is and then in the next five seconds you can send in your actual bid or ask and it only counts if it's hash matches what you sent during the first five seconds and that stops front running and then there's various attacks on the way that in ways of stopping the attacks and there's a whole literature about that but that's the way to get fairness in a public ledger sorry not fairness the way to stop front running in a public ledger and every ledger is the same in that respect except if the ledger is really fast that helps a lot because by going to rounds you're going to be slowing yourself down so you really want a ledger like hedge like hedera that's very very fast and that gets consensus very fast also if you do this thing with the times you really want finality so finality and speed are very very important for that but other than that it's just something you're building above the ledger and it doesn't matter what ledger you're dealing with so it's a big question we have a blog that goes through fairness in a lot more detail it has pictures the pictures help a lot and has that blog been no um so maybe we could put a link into the chat that would give you the blog post on fairness so that was a long answer we've talked about it before but um but you know not everybody sees everything and i think it's an important issue because hedera is really good at fairness more so than um blockchains and other things that we could talk about and the paper talks about that too so anyway good question thank you thank you leemon and yes the um the link to the blog is now in the chat for those who want to um read more details um one more question leemon on a technical level what would happen

chapters.text: if some of the main net nodes decided against a software update and just continued to use the previous consensus rules oh they fall off it's just automatic there isn't even a mechanism to do it it's just inherent in the algorithm itself what we do is every round every node has to digitally sign the hash at the root of the merkle tree of the entire state so you know about once a second every single node is digitally signing here's what i think every single account in your in your system has and what every state of the smart contract is and what all your files are and what the history of your hcs is for the last few minutes every second we're doing that and then each node collects signatures from others and if someone didn't install the software upgrade they get a different state their signature doesn't match everybody else just discards their signature it just looks like a bad signature so it just gets discarded so they basically have no effect and if they tried to send their information to a mirror node the mirror node will reject it because their signature doesn't match everybody else's signatures and so it's just they instantly get kicked off the network in a sense in a fraction of a second it's wonderful so that's what happens if you don't update the software um but we're building it so that it'll be automated so you won't even have to do anything to update the software it just happens but if you intervened and prevented it from happening you would just be automatically kicked off in a second and um just just is inherent in the algorithm all right thank you leemon um

chapters.text: which are all everybody is talking about how do you support fractional nfts for example for crowdfunding yes so nft is you have a bottle of wine you have a different serial number on each bottle and you have an nft for each bottle but what if you wanted to actually divide the bottle into pieces and sell shares of that one bottle um yeah so if you build nfts on top of our hts then what you end up having is each bottle counts as a token type it's like its own erc20 so our equivalent of a 721 an erc721 is like a bunch of erc20s which means that each of the serial numbers can be subdivided into 100 million pieces that's kind of cool actually more than that billions or trillions or whatever quadrillions lots of pieces if you want to or you can do a traditional nft and not let it be divisible and so when you create it you have the choice you can make it be completely divisible or not divisible at all you have that power and that's if you build your nfts on top of our hts you could build your nfts on top of our hcs in which case you do anything you want if you're using our consensus service to build an app net you can do anything you want and certainly you can do fractional so either way when you build nfts on us you get the power and the speed of hedera of the native token but you have the power for fractionalization and that's a pretty powerful concept that most nfts don't support and not all nfts need them but it's a useful feature all right thanks leemon uh mance

that shard only has to remember the history for the last few minutes technically only the last few seconds but we we keep a minute or two just to be safe um it's the mirror nodes that keep the entire history forever and so even the main nodes in that shard don't have to keep it it'll be the mirror nodes for that shard that have to keep the infinite history going back forever uh and and they can do entries.description:
Hedera Co-founders, Dr. Leemon Baird and Mance Harmon, join SVP of Communications, Zenobia Godschalk, to answer questions directly from the community in our monthly Town Hall.

Join our community to learn more:
Website: https://hedera.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/hedera
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hashgraph
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/hashgraph
Telegram: https://t.me/hederahashgraph
Discord: https://hedera.com/discord
Medium: https://medium.com/hashgraph
Whitepapers: https://hedera.com/papers
